headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is a Chanel, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the H.J. Heinz Company Fiscal Year 2013 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. This call is being recorded at the request
componenttext: Good morning. My name is a Chanel, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the H.J. Heinz Company Fiscal Year 2013 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. This call is being recorded at the request of the H.J. Heinz Company. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Meg Nollen, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Nollen, you may now begin the conference.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chanel, and good morning. I'd like to welcome everyone to our conference call and webcast. Copies of the slides used in today's presentation are available on our website at heinz.com. Joining me on today's call are Art Winkleblack, Executive
componenttext:
Thank you, Chanel, and good morning. I'd like to welcome everyone to our conference call and webcast. Copies of the slides used in today's presentation are available on our website at heinz.com. 
Joining me on today's call are Art Winkleblack, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Ed McMenamin, Senior Vice President, Finance. 
Before we begin with our prepared remarks, please refer to the forward-looking statements currently displayed. This is also available in this morning's earnings release and in our most recent SEC filings. 
To summarize, during our presentation, we may make forward-looking statements about our business that are intended to assist you in understanding the company and its results. We ask you to refer to our April 29, 2012, Form 10-K and today's press release, which lists some of the factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in these statements. Heinz undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by securities laws. 
We may also use non-GAAP financial measures in our presentation as the company believes such measures allow for consistent period-to-period comparison of the business. The most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures are available on the company's earnings release today and on our website at heinz.com. Our complete financial highlights pages or stack pages are now available on the Investor Relations section of heinz.com towards the bottom of the page. Please note, we plan to file our first quarter 10-Q later today. 
Finally, we'd like to request that you limit your questions during the Q&A session to one single-part question in order to ensure adequate time for all of who wish to participate and to ensure we end the call timely. 
Now with the formalities out of the way, let me turn the call over to Art Winkleblack. Art?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meg. Good morning, everyone. Today, we're pleased to take you through our first quarter performance, which marks a great start to fiscal 2013. In the quarter, we delivered robust organic sales growth, again driven by our trio of growth engines:
componenttext:
Thanks, Meg. Good morning, everyone. Today, we're pleased to take you through our first quarter performance, which marks a great start to fiscal 2013. 
In the quarter, we delivered robust organic sales growth, again driven by our trio of growth engines: Emerging Markets, Global Ketchup and our Top 15 brands. Year-over-year gross margin improvement for the first time in 5 quarters despite the tough economic environment and higher commodity costs. Continued investment in the business including marketing, Project Keystone and more boots on the ground in Emerging Markets and strong constant currency profit growth driven by higher operating income and a lower tax rate. On a reported basis, results were unfavorably impacted by foreign exchange. So overall, we're off to a very good start for the new year. 
On a constant currency basis, net sales grew by more than 4%, operating income increased 5% and EPS rose more than 15% on a like-for-like basis which excludes the impact of last year's charges for productivity initiatives. In short, strong results in a very challenging environment. 
Importantly, Q1 marked our 29th consecutive quarter of organic sales growth at nearly 5%. I think this is an important indicator of our focus on growth, the strength of our portfolio, the effectiveness of our commercial programs and consistency of performance. Our trio of growth engines, Emerging Markets, Global Ketchup and our Top 15 brands, once again drove our organic sales growth. I want to briefly get some highlights in each of these areas. 
Our Emerging Markets posted organic sales growth of almost 20%. The growth was led by Carolyn Brazil, Foodstar in China and Heinz in Russia. Importantly, in Russia, Heinz is now the #1 brand in both ketchup and total condiments. We also had strong organic sales growth in Indonesia and India. Overall, Emerging Markets represented a record 26% of Heinz sales in Q1, which is our high watermark in the year for emerging market mix given the timing of Ramadan. 
Of note this quarter in Brazil, it has been the business processes and the implementation of SAP allowed us to eliminate the 1 month lag in closing the books there, so our results include an extra month in Brazil, which was partially offset by the planned sales reduction in Long Fong related to the significant streamlining we executed in that business last quarter. 
And turning to Global Ketchup, we posted a 3.7% organic growth overlapping more than 8% organic growth last year. Our Emerging Markets are Brazil, Russia and China, delivered strong double-digit growth, driven by both retail and Foodservice channels. U.K. led our developed markets in ketchup growth aided by innovative line extensions like ketchup with balsamic vinegar and now Indian spices. 
Turning to our Top 15 brands, we posted nearly 6% organic sales growth in Q1. As a result, these core brands have grown to nearly 3 quarters of our portfolio. It's an important advantage for us and it allows us to more tightly and effectively focus our commercial resources and investment dollars. 
Now let's take a quick look at each of our geographic regions. Turning first to North American Consumer Products, our results reflected solid and encouraging performance in the U.S. Excluding the 2 product lines we exited last year, Boston market, which is included in divestitures, T.G.I. Friday's frozen meals, organic sales in our core U.S. business were up more than 3%. The solid growth is reflective of stronger market shares and indeed we grew volume share in 9 of our 12 U.S. retail product categories over the last 12-week period while increasing our average net price. 
I'm pleased to report good progress on Ore-Ida as well, where sales increased as a mid-single digit rate during the quarter. We've been working with our current partners to optimize Ore-Ida pricing on the shelves which is just beginning to have a positive effect. We also posted mid- ingle-digit sales growth in Smart Ones and a 2% volume increase in ketchup. 
Operating income was off slightly the prior year impacted by higher commodity cost, sales mix and increased investment in marketing. And finally, we went live on SAP in Canada during the quarter and incurred some startup challenges there. 
U.S. Foodservice delivered excellent results for the quarter. Organic sales grew about 2.5%, driven by price increases implemented last year to cover inflation. Encouragingly, volume was stable and the trajectory's been improving, driven by more favorable QSR trends and our success in penetrating noncommercial channels. Operating income grew at a double-digit rate reflecting higher pricing and lower costs, literally aided by the benefits from last year's restructuring initiatives. 
As Ed will discuss shortly, we completed the sale of our U.S. Foodservice desserts business this quarter and we continue to enhance our focus on branded ketchup and sauces. 
Turning next to Europe, the segment generated very solid constant currency results for the quarter with sales up 1.5 points and profit up almost 8%. Organic sales growth was 2% driven by pricing. The U.K. and Russia continue to drive very strong growth, particularly on ketchup, while sales in Continental Europe and Italy continue to be impacted by weak economies and categories. During the quarter, we increased marketing and continued to drive the European change agenda in order to meet the evolving environment there. Additionally, we have successfully implemented Keystone in Germany while also divesting a small unprofitable soup business in Germany and consolidating back-office activities into the Netherlands. 
Moving to Asia/Pacific, constant currency sales grew by more than 4%, led by Indonesia, India and China and by soy sauce from a category standpoint. This growth includes a negative impact on streamlining Long Fong, which cut the size of that business in 1/2 as we executed or exited 2 or 4 factories and focused on higher growth, higher-margin products. The region posted 30% profit growth, reflecting improved net pricing, productivity, sales mix and a strong rebound in Australia, which was aided by last year's restructuring initiatives. Additionally, we'll continue to increase investments in marketing, and in sales capabilities across Emerging Markets in the region. 
The Rest of World segment reported 32% constant currency sales growth for the quarter, driven by very strong year-over-year growth in Brazil, plus the extra month, as well as double-digit growth in Mexico and the Middle East. Venezuelan sales were down for the quarter as a result of the macroeconomic issues in the country. Rest of World delivered 3% constant currency profit growth, lapping more than 100% growth last year, with Brazil's strong performance being partially offset by weakness in Venezuela. As mentioned, several recent actions we've taken to continue streamlining, reshaping and strengthening our portfolio. These included completing the sale of our U.S. Foodservice desserts, business which we announced at Analyst Day in May, exiting subscale frozen businesses in U.S. retail by divesting the Boston market license and discontinuing T.G.I. Friday's premium frozen meals, divesting a small unprofitable soup business in Germany and rightsizing our Long Fong frozen business in China. Now these and many other actions we've executed over the last decade has helped focus the portfolio on those brands and categories where we have the capabilities and position to win. Ketchup and sauces are the crown jewel which now represent almost 1/2 of our sales. This is an important shift in the portfolio which we're continuing to drive aggressively. 
Now with that said, I'll turn it over to Ed to cover the rest of the financials. Ed?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Art, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through their first quarter financial highlights to reflect strong constant currency growth in our key P&L metrics. But before I go through the results, as Art referenced earlier, in May, we completed
componenttext:
Thanks, Art, and good morning, everyone. I'll take you through their first quarter financial highlights to reflect strong constant currency growth in our key P&L metrics. But before I go through the results, as Art referenced earlier, in May, we completed the sale of our U.S. Foodservice frozen desserts business, that resulted in a $0.07 charge to EPS, so long with last year's results are reflected in discontinued operations. Now let's walk through the financials. 
Here, you can see 3 different views of EPS. At any way to look at it, we delivered double-digit growth. Starting on the left, our results from continuing operations, which exclude the productivity charges last year, reflect 10% growth at $0.87 this year. On a constant currency basis, EPS would have been $0.91, up 15% increase from the comparable base last year. And finally, from the total company reported basis, EPS was $0.80 this year, up 14%. The balance of the presentation will focus on the company's results from continuing operations compared to last year's results, excluding productivity charges. And as a reminder, in Q1 of fiscal '12, the productivity charges were $41 million pretax or $0.09 of EPS. 
Turning to the P&L scorecard, constant currency sales were up over 4%, but down 1.5% after a sizable foreign exchange headwind. Gross margin was 35.9%, up slightly as higher pricing and productivity improvements were able to more than offset commodity inflation. Looking forward, as we progress through the year, we expect pricing and productivity to continue to outpace commodity cost increases and margins will build significantly throughout the year. 
We continue to increase our investment in consumer marketing which was up 4.5% on a constant currency basis with the incremental spending split evenly between developed and emerging markets. For perspective, we expect a sizable ramp-up of marketing in Q2 and throughout the year. Operating income is up 5% on a constant currency basis as higher organize sales growth and effective cost management offset unfavorable commodities while also supporting increased marketing and incremental investments in both Project Keystone and emerging market capabilities. After the impact of currency, OI was about flat. EPS of $0.87 benefited from effective tax rate of approximately 18% this year compared to 24% last year. In Q1, and to a greater extent in Q2, we expect the benefit from foreign tax planning initiatives with a full year estimate for the tax rate remains in the low 20s with higher-than-average rates in the second half of the year. 
Looking at the Q sales drivers, our organic sales growth of 4 .8% was fairly balance between volume and price. Volume improved 2.5%, driven by Emerging Markets, led by a very strong performance in Brazil, as well as improvements in the U.S. and the U.K. The Brazilian results reflect exceptional normalized organic growth of 45% as further aided by an additional month's results. The majority of the benefit from the additional month was offset by the planned exits of T.G.I. Friday's frozen meals in the U.S. and the streamlining of the Long Fong business in China to focus on only more profitable products and regions. Higher pricing at 2.3% was driven by price increases in most of the Emerging Markets, particularly Latin America and China, as well as in the developed markets of the U.S. and U.K. The divestitures of the Boston market brand in the U.S. and a small soup business in Germany decreased sales by 60 basis points. And finally, foreign exchange reduced our top line by 5.6%. 
Looking at sales by category, Ketchup and Sauces, our most important category, led the way with nearly 6% organic growth. Meals & Snacks reported overall organic growth of 3.1%, and notably, both the ambient and frozen segments were positive as contributions from both volume and price in each. Infant/Nutrition recorded 2.3% organic growth, driven by a 12% increase in Emerging Markets. 
Art cover each of the segments performance in detail, but here you can quickly see all of our segments delivered positive organic growth this quarter. 
As I noted earlier, our gross margin was up slightly from last year with a 10 basis point improvement to 35.9%. The market basket for our commodities was up almost 4%, primarily due to sweeteners, most notably in Indonesia, and beans in Europe, as well as glass globally. So the contributions from pricing and productivity more than offset this inflation. 
Now let's move to the balance sheet scorecard. Capital expenditures were 3% of sales, up 40 basis points from last year and we're still anticipating spending of approximately 4% of sales for the full fiscal year as we support growth in our Emerging Markets, as well as the continued rollout of Project Keystone. Cash conversion cycle delivered a substantial improvement of 6 days driven by receivables and inventory and represents a record low CCC of 36 days, around 1/3 of where we were a decade ago. In line with our expectations, operating free cash flow was an outflow of $25 million. This reflects $42 million of cash paid this quarter for fiscal 2012 productivity initiatives. While last year, QOWC benefit from the timing of drawdowns on our accounts receivable securitization programs. Our debt to EBITDA at 2.1x was up slightly the prior year, driven by modestly higher net debt, and I'm pleased to point out that Fitch recently raised our debt rating to BBB+. ROIC was nearly 20% for the quarter, up 110 basis points from this time last year, driven by our 10% increase in net income this quarter. 
In summary, we're pleased with our results in Q1, delivering almost 5% organic sales growth, constant currency operating income growth in excess of 5% and double-digit EPS growth. 
With that, I'll now turn it back to Art to update you on our full year outlook.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Now just a couple of remarks on our outlook before we open it up to your questions. With Q1 behind us, let's take a look at what we expect for the balance of the fiscal year. Beginning with Q2, we expect another quarter of organic sales growth
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Now just a couple of remarks on our outlook before we open it up to your questions. With Q1 behind us, let's take a look at what we expect for the balance of the fiscal year. Beginning with Q2, we expect another quarter of organic sales growth at around 4%; improving gross margin based on the combination of net pricing and productivity more than offsetting commodity inflation; implementation of our planned incremental investments and marketing, Project Keystone and sales capabilities in Emerging Markets to drive top line growth and further strengthen our foundation for the future; marketing spending in particular will increase significantly in Q2 behind a number of new initiatives in the U.S., U.K. and emerging market; the Q2 tax rate will be very favorable at a low double-digit rates based on the flow of our foreign tax planning initiatives. And note that while our tax rate will be quite favorable through the first half of the year, we still anticipate that our full year tax rate will be in the low 20s. And foreign currency will continue to be unfavorable. Overall, we expect constant currency EPS growth of around 10% in Q2. 
Importantly, for the full year, we are reaffirming our FY '13 constant currency targets. This reflects the strong start we made in the first quarter and our confidence in our brands, our people, our plans and our ability to respond to ever-changing market conditions around the world. 
So to sum up, our fiscal year is off to a strong start. Our key growth drivers, Emerging Markets, Top 15 brands and Global Ketchup, continue to provide strong and consistent growth. The savings from last year's productivity initiatives are coming in according to our expectations. We expect sequential improvement in our year-over-year gross margin results. And finally, we are on track to execute the $120 million of planned investments we discussed in May to help drive the business for sustainable long-term growth. 
With that, I'll turn the call back over to Meg and then we'll open it up to your questions. Meg?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay, Chanel, we're ready for questions.
componenttext: Great. Okay, Chanel, we're ready for questions.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Christopher Growe from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Christopher Growe from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a couple of quick questions. And the first one just relates to the Emerging Markets. You had obviously very solid growth again this quarter. I'm curious if you're seeing any slowdown in some of the markets like China or we keep hearin
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a couple of quick questions. And the first one just relates to the Emerging Markets. You had obviously very solid growth again this quarter. I'm curious if you're seeing any slowdown in some of the markets like China or we keep hearing about a slowdown. Certainly, it's been more focused on industrials, industrial sort of companies, but I'm curious to see that kind of linger into the consumer world.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Chris, as you saw, we posted 19% organic growth in our Emerging Markets and I think even if you take out some of the onetime decisions like the extra month in Brazil and things that were still at about 15% organic growth. So we feel very good about where
componenttext: Chris, as you saw, we posted 19% organic growth in our Emerging Markets and I think even if you take out some of the onetime decisions like the extra month in Brazil and things that were still at about 15% organic growth. So we feel very good about where emerging markets are going. I think to your point, a lot of the discussion of the slowdown in China, I guess they've slowed down the GDP growth rate of about 8% at this point which most countries would love to have. But I think it's more on the industrial side. Frankly, the exploding middle-class in these emerging markets are just coming into their own in terms of ability to afford packaged food and so I think we are very, very well positioned and we feel very good about the ongoing trajectory of what we think the growth rates will be of our kinds of products.

componenttext: Let me clarify. The $120 million, David, if you recall from Analyst Day, that $70 million of that was from marketing and the rest in other investments within the business. And the marketing really is, as I tried to allude to, will ramp up through the remaining quarters. So marketing spending was up on a constant currency basis in Q1, but it will be up very significantly in Q2 and then in the remainder of the year, basically timed with the timing of our programs, the ideas and ready for the initiatives. So we're feeling good about the trajectory in the plans for going forward.

componenttext: Yes, you're going to see Heinz spend in marketing like you've never seen us before and we're very excited about all of the launches and the brand support that is coming out, and in fact, we're going to show you a lot of that at the upcoming back-to-school conference. So get ready, it's on. Heinz is on the Olympics. We've done a number of things, so very exciting.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So we fully expect to spend at least that $70 million of incremental marketing that we talked about in May.
componenttext: Yes. So we fully expect to spend at least that $70 million of incremental marketing that we talked about in May.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: The Europe division, you mentioned that conditions were tough there. Are conditions, in your opinion, in terms of the consumer getting worse there? And are you expecting even budgeting for increasingly difficult consumer environment through the fiscal yea
componenttext: The Europe division, you mentioned that conditions were tough there. Are conditions, in your opinion, in terms of the consumer getting worse there? And are you expecting even budgeting for increasingly difficult consumer environment through the fiscal year in that region?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, David, it's kind of interesting how Europe is it's sort of a tale of 2 cities for us. If you go to your end of the continent, we're performing extremely well. So Russia and the East in particular had a great quarter. We feel really good about the mome
componenttext: No, David, it's kind of interesting how Europe is it's sort of a tale of 2 cities for us. If you go to your end of the continent, we're performing extremely well. So Russia and the East in particular had a great quarter. We feel really good about the momentum in Russia both from a top line and a gross margin standpoint. And the U.K. business continues to be a fortress for us given the strength of our brand equities there and the power of the innovation and execution within the business. So at both ends of the continent, we feel very good about things. To your point, it's a tough market in the middle of the continent. Continental Europe and Italy, consumer confidence is low, unemployment is high, and so it's a challenging market there, and I think we continue to evolve our products and our packaging to meet that environment. And I'm really pleased that we've got a good strong head start on driving the European agenda with what we're doing with Keystone, what we're doing with the supply chain consolidation.

componenttextpreview: Innovation Center.
componenttext: Innovation Center.

componenttext: With the Innovation Center so lots of things going on to address it. so I'm not so sure that we expect things in the middle of the continent to get too much worse, but we're sure not expecting it to get better anytime soon.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the profit growth with the high single-digit organic, the story there was largely the productivity and the restructuring from last year flowing through? Or is that, it's a difficult push and that's still the promotion efficiency efforts that you have
componenttext: And the profit growth with the high single-digit organic, the story there was largely the productivity and the restructuring from last year flowing through? Or is that, it's a difficult push and that's still the promotion efficiency efforts that you have been ongoing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's all of the above. So we're certainly Gettings restructuring benefits we had expected so that's a good thing. We're continuing to drive productivity initiative this year, particularly value engineering. Strong organic top line growth in some o
componenttext: I think it's all of the above. So we're certainly Gettings restructuring benefits we had expected so that's a good thing. We're continuing to drive productivity initiative this year, particularly value engineering. Strong organic top line growth in some of our markets is certainly helping out as well. And again, with regard to Europe in particular, it's driven at both ends of the continent.

componenttext: Yes, the 1 month was worth roughly $35 million on a gross basis, and keep in mind, though, that a lot of that was offset by the decisions we made in Long Fong and the exit of T.G.I.F. meals, but roughly $35 million at the top line. The bottom line is less than $0.01, so basically immaterial.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And a question on North America. Dave Woodward has been there for not too long, yes. I imagine he still trying to get his feet firmly planted. Any early read on what we may expect to see differently coming out of that market with the new l
componenttext: That's helpful. And a question on North America. Dave Woodward has been there for not too long, yes. I imagine he still trying to get his feet firmly planted. Any early read on what we may expect to see differently coming out of that market with the new leadership?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Dave is bringing great energy and enthusiasm to the role and he's working to drive what we would call a demand-driven recovery, so I think he's focused on the big brands and you saw that we've exited a few of our smaller less advantaged brands, so
componenttext: I think Dave is bringing great energy and enthusiasm to the role and he's working to drive what we would call a demand-driven recovery, so I think he's focused on the big brands and you saw that we've exited a few of our smaller less advantaged brands, so we're really gearing the focus on those big brands. We're getting the price value offering correct across the portfolio. Once we do that, we're increasing the marketing support behind those key brands. And then under grading it all, we're driving a strong productivity to provide some fuel for growth. So I think we're doing the right things. You saw that volume shares were up in 9  out of 12 categories, so we're pleased with that while our average price is up, so investing in the business, driving some innovation and we're -- I think there's work to be done. But we're pleased Dave's on the case.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd like to start off with the gross margin outlook. I think you guys had said that you expect a 50 to 100 basis point expansion on the year. The quarter was up something about 20 basis points. So can you bridge how the pacing goes? Ed, I think you even m
componenttext: I'd like to start off with the gross margin outlook. I think you guys had said that you expect a 50 to 100 basis point expansion on the year. The quarter was up something about 20 basis points. So can you bridge how the pacing goes? Ed, I think you even mentioned in your script about the dramatic expansions that go forward because of pricing and productivity, but can you guys just expand on this a little bit so folks can get a little comfort that these expansions are on track with your plan?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, David, let me hit that first and Ed can add some color. Our gross margin was largely in line with our plan in the first quarter. We do expect the year-on-year increase in gross margin to gain sequentially. I mean, that's really driven by 3 key t
componenttext: Yes, yes, David, let me hit that first and Ed can add some color. Our gross margin was largely in line with our plan in the first quarter. We do expect the year-on-year increase in gross margin to gain sequentially. I mean, that's really driven by 3 key things. I think you'll see somewhat better pricing in the back half on a net price basis. We'll have a different and more favorable business unit and product mix as well. And we've got this heavy focus going on in terms of value engineering that combines with the restructuring programs and savings that we have from last year. So all of those things work to our benefit. The other thing we're seeing is over time, we're seeing the gross margins improving in our newer businesses with Quero in Brazil and Foodstar in China. As usual, when you buy these businesses, the gross margins tend to start out relatively low, but the opportunity to drive those northward, we're certainly seeing that. And so we expect that to continue. The other thing I might add is that we're beginning to leverage the scale and efficiencies of our consolidated European supply chain hub, so we feel good about where we're going there. We had our new global head of procurement, John Dixon, joined not too long ago and I think he's starting to make some traction. So net-net, we feel good about the levers and the trajectory as we look forward.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I'd follow up with a question on cost savings and input costs. The cost savings question, I believe this year, you're looking for total cost saves of $250 million, can you just update that? Is that still the number? Is it any better? And then w
componenttext: Okay. Then I'd follow up with a question on cost savings and input costs. The cost savings question, I believe this year, you're looking for total cost saves of $250 million, can you just update that? Is that still the number? Is it any better? And then what did you realize in the first quarter and how was the pacing of that go throughout the year? And then just a quick update on input cost inflation and how much is hedged and what's the rate of market inflation that you guys typically could? I know you said the quarter, but what's the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of productivity from particularly supply chain, I think we're on better than target so far and we believe we have some opportunity there and we'll see as the year goes along and we'll play that out. But productivity is running according to p
componenttext: Yes, in terms of productivity from particularly supply chain, I think we're on better than target so far and we believe we have some opportunity there and we'll see as the year goes along and we'll play that out. But productivity is running according to plan or better. And in terms of market inflation, I think the market inflation estimates are still pretty much in line with what we had talked about at Analyst Day and if I'm recalling right, that was around 4%.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you've seen a lot of inflation in a lot of commodities out there, and fortunately for us, we've locked in a good portion of our year. So the market inflation could be somewhere in the neighborhood of 4-plus, 4 to %, but that's highly dependen
componenttext: Yes. I think you've seen a lot of inflation in a lot of commodities out there, and fortunately for us, we've locked in a good portion of our year. So the market inflation could be somewhere in the neighborhood of 4-plus, 4 to %, but that's highly dependent on several of these crops out there. The big impact Ed had mentioned previously, sweeteners and in particular, Indonesia. So palm sugars is a very, very strong right now on pricing. So but the good news for us is that we have -- that will come in largely line with expectation because we have largely taken that off the table.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we saw things have gone ahead and start things going up and he covered a bit more than we would normally at this time of the year and the way things are looking, that's really advantageous. I think also going back to the productivity issues t
componenttext: Yes, I think we saw things have gone ahead and start things going up and he covered a bit more than we would normally at this time of the year and the way things are looking, that's really advantageous. I think also going back to the productivity issues that we were going through the major plant moves and that thing last year, the operations guys were focused on that. Now that they've got that running, what they're focused on is we've got the normal type of productivity that's sort of been followed a little bit that they can really focus on and it will start delivering benefits in the second half of the year on top of the productivity restructuring charges from last year.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's well put and you heard the headlines about corn prices because of the heat and drought and things like that. But to Meg's point, we are virtually all hedged on a lot of those key commodities. So we really are pretty confident on our ou
componenttext: Yes, I think that's well put and you heard the headlines about corn prices because of the heat and drought and things like that. But to Meg's point, we are virtually all hedged on a lot of those key commodities. So we really are pretty confident on our outlook on the commodity costs.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney from Janney Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney from Janney Capital Markets.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I know you covered this a little bit. I just want -- can you give me a detail about what are the 2 or 3 big factors that drive the swings in this tax rate? Because you have -- I mean is this consistent with what you thought coming into the year the taxes
componenttext: I know you covered this a little bit. I just want -- can you give me a detail about what are the 2 or 3 big factors that drive the swings in this tax rate? Because you have -- I mean is this consistent with what you thought coming into the year the taxes would flow this way? And what causes them, the intra-quarter variations so much? I'm just thinking how much of that laps, the structural stop that laps in fiscal '13 or '15 or stuff that is dependent on some of the factors, discrete to 2013?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: If you go back to last year, we've got a similar discrete transaction in Q2. We were able to execute a similar transaction in Q1 of this year and we're planning for another one in the following quarter. Some tax planning initiatives are spread over evenly
componenttext: If you go back to last year, we've got a similar discrete transaction in Q2. We were able to execute a similar transaction in Q1 of this year and we're planning for another one in the following quarter. Some tax planning initiatives are spread over evenly over quarters. And over the years, it's obviously very discrete but the 2 that we're trying to hear is very discrete. But what the tax guys are looking at is we continue to examine programs into the future years to try to keep that rate down in the low 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And we have the benefit this quarter. As we did last year, 1Q, the U.K. again took its corporate tax rate down from 200 basis points, doing the right thing to incent businesses. And so we're very pleased with that, but you see the benefit of t
componenttext: Absolutely. And we have the benefit this quarter. As we did last year, 1Q, the U.K. again took its corporate tax rate down from 200 basis points, doing the right thing to incent businesses. And so we're very pleased with that, but you see the benefit of that because that has a bit of a retroactive impact and a onetime big benefit in the quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think that's another advantage of our having most of our sales overseas. These foreign tax opportunity did present themselves and we have a team that's scaling the world to look for it, taking advantage of that.
componenttext: I think that's another advantage of our having most of our sales overseas. These foreign tax opportunity did present themselves and we have a team that's scaling the world to look for it, taking advantage of that.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the key point, is given our significant global mix of sales in international that allows us a lot more tax planning opportunities in those foreign jurisdictions, and frankly, the foreign jurisdictions seem to understand that a lower ta
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the key point, is given our significant global mix of sales in international that allows us a lot more tax planning opportunities in those foreign jurisdictions, and frankly, the foreign jurisdictions seem to understand that a lower tax rate is a good thing for their economy, so that's where they're moving to do. To your other points, we constantly look for opportunities to drive down the tax rate. Over the long term, you saw that had a low tax rate in the low 20s last year. We expect it to be this year and we're certainly working on initiatives to continue that going forward in the future years now. We'll talk more about that as the year goes along, but that is certainly the expectation and the plan that we would continue driving those kinds of numbers.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Remember, Heinz is 2/3 international or non-U.S. sales, so our tax rate will vary accordingly.
componenttext: Remember, Heinz is 2/3 international or non-U.S. sales, so our tax rate will vary accordingly.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: By the way, I wish that the timing of these things was perfectly predictable and even through the quarters, but that's just not the reality of the way taxes work.
componenttext: By the way, I wish that the timing of these things was perfectly predictable and even through the quarters, but that's just not the reality of the way taxes work.

componenttext: This is actually Brian for Thilo. Most of my questions have been answered but I just wanted to touch on the Dip & Squeeze patent lawsuit. Is there any product risk there? Any update on what's going on there?

componenttextpreview: We view that as a frivolous situation and we will be defending it rigorously and we're not overly worried about it.
componenttext: We view that as a frivolous situation and we will be defending it rigorously and we're not overly worried about it.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So to follow up on the tax rate, the implication there, it sounds like if you're talking about, I don't know, 12%, 13% for the second quarter, if I'm hearing the low double-digit number right, to get to about a 23% number for the year, you have to do abou
componenttext: So to follow up on the tax rate, the implication there, it sounds like if you're talking about, I don't know, 12%, 13% for the second quarter, if I'm hearing the low double-digit number right, to get to about a 23% number for the year, you have to do about 30% tax rate in the back half of the year. I just want to make sure that math is correct.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: It'll be upper 20s.
componenttext: It'll be upper 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Upper 20s.
componenttext: Upper 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right, but the tax guidance for the year is flat and last year was 21.7%, okay?
componenttext: Right, but the tax guidance for the year is flat and last year was 21.7%, okay?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then the question I have as a follow-up to that, would be a lot -- there's a lot of companies out there now that have a lot of international sales. You certainly are in that group and you've done a great job building your
componenttext: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then the question I have as a follow-up to that, would be a lot -- there's a lot of companies out there now that have a lot of international sales. You certainly are in that group and you've done a great job building your global portfolio to get there, but not every company is able to define these discrete transactions, as you call them, as often as you do and I think the credit goes to your tax department generally for finding them, but I'm curious what do you credit that to? What are you able to do, without disparaging other companies that may be other companies aren't able to find, it does seem like you're able to get lower taxes and other companies on an average basis even other companies that may have even more of international exposure that you do. So I'm just curious you can help me understand that a little bit.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have a team downstairs that is very focused on it. In addition, we've a lot of outsiders that come in and present opportunities. When we go to the various countries, we try to get very familiar with what they launch, what the opportunities are.
componenttext: I mean, we have a team downstairs that is very focused on it. In addition, we've a lot of outsiders that come in and present opportunities. When we go to the various countries, we try to get very familiar with what they launch, what the opportunities are. We engage local tax experts and we take it very seriously. It is an opportunity when you've got the geographic stance that we have to take advantage of that. So most of these ideas are not internally generated. We listen attentively to other people with ideas so if they work with our portfolio and try to capitalize on them best we can, so very active team.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I suspect our business unit mix is an advantage for us, but I think at the end of the day, we have a great tax team that does exceptionally good work.
componenttext: Yes, I suspect our business unit mix is an advantage for us, but I think at the end of the day, we have a great tax team that does exceptionally good work.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012

componenttext: Very quickly, Meg, when you talk about expecting constant currency EPS growth of about 10%, what's the base on that? There've been some divestitures, some SKU rationalization, is it the $0.81 base? Or how do we look at that from Q2 '12?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is based off the $0.81 roughly, yes.
componenttext: Yes, it is based off the $0.81 roughly, yes.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger, Morgan Stanley.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get your thoughts on the pricing and promotional environment in North America, how you characterize things at the moment. Are you feeling any more or less confident than you were 3 months ago and being able to achieve whatever level of
componenttext: So I just wanted to get your thoughts on the pricing and promotional environment in North America, how you characterize things at the moment. Are you feeling any more or less confident than you were 3 months ago and being able to achieve whatever level of pricing was embedded in your initial fiscal '13 plan? And should we consider the level of pricing we saw in North America in Q1 to be sort of reflective of what you're looking for, for the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think to your point, it's a competitive word out there and no doubt about it developed markets including the U.S. are certainly challenged. But I think it's all about balance. It isn't a black-and-white thing and it varies by category and it varie
componenttext: Matt, I think to your point, it's a competitive word out there and no doubt about it developed markets including the U.S. are certainly challenged. But I think it's all about balance. It isn't a black-and-white thing and it varies by category and it varies by country. So it goes business to business and we're trying to be verry nuanced in our approach. So list pricing actions, in some cases, are not in the cards. On the flip side of that, we have driven, I think, very effectively against making our promotion spending more efficient and more effective in many cases both for us and for our joint customers. So I think Dave Moran's been doing a nice job with his team over in Europe on that. Dave Woodward certainly is focused on that arena. We're focused on it in Australia as well. So I'd say it's a difficult environment, but we're -- I think, we've got the tools and the knowledge to be more nuanced and more effective at it than maybe we would've been in the past. And then fundamentally, you probably got more pricing power in Emerging Markets just based on the fragmented trade environment and the more fragmented competitive set we see in those markets. So we believe we're on track to our plans for pricing, but it's certainly not an easy environment.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as always, the consumers going to pay for what they perceive to be value and we have to get that value equation right. In some cases, that means prices go up. In some cases, that means we get a little more competitive. And the key is the inno
componenttext: Yes, I think as always, the consumers going to pay for what they perceive to be value and we have to get that value equation right. In some cases, that means prices go up. In some cases, that means we get a little more competitive. And the key is the innovations, the brand support driving the consumer to the shelf, doing all the right things by the brand, and I know Dave Woodward and the team is driving for this long-term sustainable growth in their business, so stay tuned.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, and a very quick housekeeping, apologies if I missed this, but have -- can you provide any set of updated FX guidance either on the sales or EPS line for the full year?
componenttext: Okay, and a very quick housekeeping, apologies if I missed this, but have -- can you provide any set of updated FX guidance either on the sales or EPS line for the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think when we talked to you guys in May, we had expected that the FX would be an impact of about $0.06 for the full year. You saw that we got hit with $0.04 just in Q1 alone. If recollection serves me correctly, if the rates stayed around where they are
componenttext: I think when we talked to you guys in May, we had expected that the FX would be an impact of about $0.06 for the full year. You saw that we got hit with $0.04 just in Q1 alone. If recollection serves me correctly, if the rates stayed around where they are now, you might see another $0.05 over that successive we were talking about, another $0.04 to $0.05. Having said that, we tend to not really adjust our outlook for ForEx this early in the year because you're starting to see a lot of volatility. And frankly, over the recent days, we're seeing some of the currency rates move slightly in our favor. So it's hard to say, it's early in the year yet, but I think there's probably another $0.04 to $0.05 if nothing changed on currency for the full year.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Dickerson, consumer edge.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Dickerson, consumer edge.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of quick questions for you. I guess the first was just on cash. I know you said, I think you put in the prepared remarks and discussed that you have cash over $1 billion-plus now. I know it could be very small change, but before you were
componenttext: So just a couple of quick questions for you. I guess the first was just on cash. I know you said, I think you put in the prepared remarks and discussed that you have cash over $1 billion-plus now. I know it could be very small change, but before you were saying, I think $1.1 billion. And in line with that, I also saw I guess the cash balances at the end of the year was a little bit higher than what we're seeing in Q1. So I was wondering if you could just kind of provide a little color as to why there should be incrementally more pressure on operating free cash flow.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me be clear, we didn't consciously change anything in our guidance. So what we said in May, that is our outlook for cash flow. I think Q1 was impacted by 3 things, as Ed alluded to. First, we had the carryover productivity spending from our restr
componenttext: Yes, let me be clear, we didn't consciously change anything in our guidance. So what we said in May, that is our outlook for cash flow. I think Q1 was impacted by 3 things, as Ed alluded to. First, we had the carryover productivity spending from our restructuring activities last year. That was $40-some million which took our cash negative for the quarter. Capital spending was up a bit and then there was some timing of receivables securitizations. But if you remember, we are a very back-half-oriented company. If you go back over the history of Heinz over the last 10 years, given the crop cycles in the northern hemisphere, we tend to be back-half-loaded in terms of cash flow. So we feel like we're on track for that. We've got a strong history of delivering cash. So we're tracking to it. As always, a lot of hard work to be done, but we're on track. Your other question was on cash balance? Refresh my Memory, Rob.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. That's 1Q, but that's just we're buying inventories as crops are coming in, we're setting up for the year, so that's carryover productivity cash, so that's normal.
componenttext: Right. That's 1Q, but that's just we're buying inventories as crops are coming in, we're setting up for the year, so that's carryover productivity cash, so that's normal.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's normal cyclicality.
componenttext: That's normal cyclicality.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then the second question is just a bit broader is if I look you released yesterday, EPS constant currency a little up over 15%. You're saying, I guess, for Q2, that you're expecting a low double-digit tax rate, but then for the full yea
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then the second question is just a bit broader is if I look you released yesterday, EPS constant currency a little up over 15%. You're saying, I guess, for Q2, that you're expecting a low double-digit tax rate, but then for the full year, you expect similar to what you guided to the Investor Day. So that should be aligned going up in the back half. It sounds like there's a little bit more investment coming in Q2 and really in the back half. So if you're not increasing guidance on constant currency from $0.05 to $0.08 even though you did in Q1 and then Q2 would seem like you would have to be low bit higher than guidance, too, just because of the tax rate again, is it -- are you just playing it safe in Q1 because it's early in the fiscal year? Or is what we should be expecting and modeling is basically a deceleration of EPS growth into the back half of the fiscal year really because the tax rate rolls off?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind 2 things, that first, the tax rate does get higher in the back half. It's not about that, so that's largely a timing issue, but we are investing heavily in the business in the back half of the year. So some of that $120 million investme
componenttext: Well, keep in mind 2 things, that first, the tax rate does get higher in the back half. It's not about that, so that's largely a timing issue, but we are investing heavily in the business in the back half of the year. So some of that $120 million investment is more back-half-loaded than front half just given the timing of the initiatives. So it's a combination of investment and then the timing of tax. But I think if you look back at our history, we've always shied away from moving guidance in the first, our outlook in the first quarter. It's still early yet in the year. We'll see how things continue to progress. It's a volatile world out there, so I think we'll talk to you further on that at the end of Q2. But as we say, we have a history of trying to invest in the business to make sure that our growth is sustainable over the long term.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as your modeling, go ahead and risk please. This is a company that focuses on its targets. We've got a pretty broad target, 3 52 to 3 62 constant currency guidance. And when the company tends to exceed, we tend to reinvest to drive sustainable gr
componenttext: Sure. So as your modeling, go ahead and risk please. This is a company that focuses on its targets. We've got a pretty broad target, 3 52 to 3 62 constant currency guidance. And when the company tends to exceed, we tend to reinvest to drive sustainable growth. So we've got a lot of very strong investments this year, and but to Art's point, it's the first quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right, certainly.
componenttext: Right, certainly.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Lazar of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Lazar of Barclays.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up quickly on I think it was Ed's comment where he mentioned that in frozen, I think both volume and price were contributors in the quarter. So I wanted to make sure I have that right. And if I do, when was sort of last time you ha
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up quickly on I think it was Ed's comment where he mentioned that in frozen, I think both volume and price were contributors in the quarter. So I wanted to make sure I have that right. And if I do, when was sort of last time you had that combination of that balance, if you will, in the frozen space? And was there anything in this quarter in particular that was either one-off about that I shouldn't expect that type of better balance going forward for the year, whether it's promotional we oriented or what have you or are we just getting back to a better balance given some of the changes in the price points and things that you're doing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: You did hear right. That is what I said. When the last time that occurred, I can't tell you offhand.
componenttext: You did hear right. That is what I said. When the last time that occurred, I can't tell you offhand.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's been a while, Andrew. There's a lot of discipline, there's been a lot of hard work by the brand team doing the right thing on the shelf, a lot of great innovation that's out there. There are so many nuances in the Nielsen data that we know you can't
componenttext: It's been a while, Andrew. There's a lot of discipline, there's been a lot of hard work by the brand team doing the right thing on the shelf, a lot of great innovation that's out there. There are so many nuances in the Nielsen data that we know you can't see. The main thing I would point out to you is Nielsen data is cash register ring, and so if the retailer makes some adjustments to their margin levels, that will reflect in Nielsen data. You think it's up, but it's not up. So Heinz is doing the right thing. The frozen team's working hard, the innovation's driving, but to your point, we haven't seen that balance. I'll have to go back, I don't have -- it's one of the factoids I don't have with me. You stumped me. But we'll go back and look for that. But kudos to the North American frozen team, they're working really hard.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, Andrew, yes, to that point, we're pleased with both frozen and ambient were up. Ambient was up a bit more than frozen, but frozen being up nonetheless, and I think part of that is that we continue to focus the portfolio on our bigger brands. And
componenttext: I think, Andrew, yes, to that point, we're pleased with both frozen and ambient were up. Ambient was up a bit more than frozen, but frozen being up nonetheless, and I think part of that is that we continue to focus the portfolio on our bigger brands. And so this is all about investing behind the core brands, the Power Brands that we can get to buying from the counter. Over time, I'd like to continue that because that's where I think the growth can be driven quite successfully.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Also keep in mind, the Long Fong business that we discussed was actually a headwind into the frozen volumes down this quarter.
componenttext: Also keep in mind, the Long Fong business that we discussed was actually a headwind into the frozen volumes down this quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you for pointing that out. Last thing, it's immediately more qualitative, but I think also in addition to a change as of top of NACP, you also had a fairly recent change in head of sales there with John Heinz and trying to get a sense of perhaps wha
componenttext: Thank you for pointing that out. Last thing, it's immediately more qualitative, but I think also in addition to a change as of top of NACP, you also had a fairly recent change in head of sales there with John Heinz and trying to get a sense of perhaps what kind of most clear and present terms of opportunities that you get a sense coming from him as well.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think David's bringing a high level of energies plugged in and he's got a track record of strong innovation and doing some great things in the U.K. We have every expectation that he'll do that in the U.S. as well. And so -- but it's early days and imple
componenttext: I think David's bringing a high level of energies plugged in and he's got a track record of strong innovation and doing some great things in the U.K. We have every expectation that he'll do that in the U.S. as well. And so -- but it's early days and implementing changes that he'll continue to figure out exactly what he wants to do and we'll keep you posted here.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think John is very excited about the emerging channels. There's been a lot of work that's been done, our alternate channels if you will, by the North American team, the U.S. team, and so he's really embracing that. And the opportunity that's presen
componenttext: Yes, I think John is very excited about the emerging channels. There's been a lot of work that's been done, our alternate channels if you will, by the North American team, the U.S. team, and so he's really embracing that. And the opportunity that's present for Heinz because that's not an area that we have focused historically.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, and keep in mind, John came out of the U.S. business a few years ago and he was one of the guys that was instrumental in kicking off the trade promotion reduction program that we talked about at U.S. EP for a number of years.
componenttext: Yes, and keep in mind, John came out of the U.S. business a few years ago and he was one of the guys that was instrumental in kicking off the trade promotion reduction program that we talked about at U.S. EP for a number of years.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That discipline, and it's to welcome John back to the U.S. and a lot of good initiatives underway.
componenttext: That discipline, and it's to welcome John back to the U.S. and a lot of good initiatives underway.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow, Credit Suisse.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess my -- we did some work on operating income growth trends in the packaged food industry and I'm sure you've seen this, too, but Heinz income growth has only been, by our math, about 10% over the last 5 years when I strip out acquisitions. The group
componenttext: I guess my -- we did some work on operating income growth trends in the packaged food industry and I'm sure you've seen this, too, but Heinz income growth has only been, by our math, about 10% over the last 5 years when I strip out acquisitions. The group is 28%. And I guess this is another quarter where operating income is flat, albeit there's a currency hit. And as I look at the guidance for the rest of the year, it doesn't look like operating income is going to be a major driver of earnings growth. And it's what I use in my models to do my valuation and I think it encompasses a lot of what drives value. I'm just wondering internally, how important is the operating income growth to executive compensation. And when you look at your performance versus your peer group, are you seeing the same thing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob, operating income growth is a key element of our compensation for all of our executives that run businesses. So yes, there is no lack of focus on it. I can't recognize the operating income numbers that you're talking about. Certainly, there's For
componenttext: Yes, Rob, operating income growth is a key element of our compensation for all of our executives that run businesses. So yes, there is no lack of focus on it. I can't recognize the operating income numbers that you're talking about. Certainly, there's ForEx noise there and there's divestitures noise in there.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Investment.
componenttext: Investment.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And investment in the business. So I think all of those things play in and we may need to compare notes on that front. But operating income is a key focus for us. And frankly, even with selling investment this year, we expect very solid operating income g
componenttext: And investment in the business. So I think all of those things play in and we may need to compare notes on that front. But operating income is a key focus for us. And frankly, even with selling investment this year, we expect very solid operating income growth.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Rob, we saw your note come through and I just haven't had the time to focus on it yet. A, I think the numbers understated and we'll get with you on it if you couldn't figure that. But b, understand that this is a company that's investing and reme
componenttext: Yes. And Rob, we saw your note come through and I just haven't had the time to focus on it yet. A, I think the numbers understated and we'll get with you on it if you couldn't figure that. But b, understand that this is a company that's investing and remember that Keystone has been gearing up over the last 5 years. And we've got -- we've been spending to really get highly efficient and leverage the scale of this organization. We have tremendous productivity coming in the coming years from Keystone alone, but it is a key goal of this organization to get our margins in that top tier, and we're going to go after it. So I saw that come through, but we'll be happy to work with you and narrow that down for you, help you out.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll show you how I came to it. Here's another challenge for you guys. I've heard reinvestment a lot today and certainly at the Analyst Day, too. By then I look at the reshaping of the portfolio like the exit of T.G.I. Friday's, exit of Boston market, exi
componenttext: I'll show you how I came to it. Here's another challenge for you guys. I've heard reinvestment a lot today and certainly at the Analyst Day, too. By then I look at the reshaping of the portfolio like the exit of T.G.I. Friday's, exit of Boston market, exit of streamlining Long Fong. These are areas where a few years ago, there was significant investment in those projects. So have you -- I guess that's my challenge. It's like do you feel like this amount of reinvestment you're doing now, we're not going to look back 3 years forward and say, we have to streamline again?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I think, Rob, we're getting focused on those core Top 15 brands so we're really trying to focus where the biggest payback is. But I mean, to your point, over time, the world changes and the realities change. Consumer face change. Industry trends chang
componenttext: No. I think, Rob, we're getting focused on those core Top 15 brands so we're really trying to focus where the biggest payback is. But I mean, to your point, over time, the world changes and the realities change. Consumer face change. Industry trends change. We will always try to be out front of those trends and those changes so that we're not getting dragged along behind trends. We're anticipating and we're getting down in front of them. We think those are the right things to do to continue to strengthen the portfolio. The investments are going behind our biggest brands, not some of these smaller brands. I think one of the key statistics to keep an eye on, our metrics is that percent of our total sales that are in those Top 15 grants because those are the big powerhouse brands that I think have the leverage and the scale and the brand position to win. And so more and more, if we can focus the portfolio on those brands and then focus our resources, marketing and otherwise, on those, I think it's the right thing to do. But we're going to continue to evolve and adjust with the world that we're faced with.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And we've been talking to shareholders over the last several weeks and months, frankly, who have actually priced us for moving quickly making decisions. So we're trying some new things and if they work, we continue to support them. If they don
componenttext: Absolutely. And we've been talking to shareholders over the last several weeks and months, frankly, who have actually priced us for moving quickly making decisions. So we're trying some new things and if they work, we continue to support them. If they don't, we make our move and the shift those dollars and reallocate them. So I think Heinz is allocating its capital and its marketing dollars well and the investment in systems is mandatory. It's something we have to do. As you know, we don't have a single ERP system where we can consolidate our global world and that makes our world more difficult and we've got to get that inefficiency out, so that spend is necessary. Regarding other investment spend, we evaluate, we're highly disciplined. And as you know, Bill thinks this industry overspends in given areas and he's going to make sure that we're getting a return for his money. And if we're not, he'll pull it and move it elsewhere.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me ask 2 modeling questions. Venezuela, how much of a drag if that is in fiscal '13 compared to what happened last year? And then lastly, marketing spend, you're saying you're going to be up $70 million. Quantitatively, is it going to look a little bi
componenttext: Let me ask 2 modeling questions. Venezuela, how much of a drag if that is in fiscal '13 compared to what happened last year? And then lastly, marketing spend, you're saying you're going to be up $70 million. Quantitatively, is it going to look a little bit less because of currency?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me say something about Venezuela first. I mean Venezuela was down in the first quarter and as I recall, both sales and profit wise. You've got an environment there that's a little bit up in the air. They've got a big election coming up in October and
componenttext: Let me say something about Venezuela first. I mean Venezuela was down in the first quarter and as I recall, both sales and profit wise. You've got an environment there that's a little bit up in the air. They've got a big election coming up in October and I think they are sitting back and waiting to see how things trend. So that may stabilize as we go forward. Venezuela is not a big business for us, so it's not a huge impact, but it's not -- yes, it certainly didn't help in Q1. In terms of the marketing spend, on a constant currency basis, we've talked about at least $70 million. To the extent that currency moves together direction, it could moderate from there. But I'll tell you, I suspect that we're going to have enough great ideas and enough good brand initiatives that we may go past that $70 million, we'll see.

componenttext: Well, good question. It is a very active pipeline. We've got a lot going on, on that front, and frankly, we're thrilled with the performance of our 2 most recent acquisitions in Quero and Foodstar, so we'd love to get more just like them. Obviously, I can't speak about specific opportunities, but there's a number of them that we're working. The pipeline is very full. Especially in Emerging Markets, we tend to be very thorough and patient to ensure that we end up with the right strategic fit and we don't overpay, so we're very excited about it. Were working on things. We'll keep you posted. We continue to work and focus on Emerging Markets and also in really 2 of our core categories, Ketchup and Sauces and Infant/Nutrition. So lots going on and again we'll keep you posted as time unfolds.

All right, well, we look forward to seeing many of you next week at the Barclays Back-to-School Conference in Boston where Art will present Wednesday, September 5. The time is now 9:45 a.m. and as always, Mary Ann and I will be around today to answer any follow-up questions. The whole IR team, the mainline is (412) 456-6020. Have a  great day.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
