componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Palmer of UBS.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: A quick housekeeping question. I didn't pick up on the slide, the marketing reinvestment of $120 million, is that front-weighted for the year?
componenttext: A quick housekeeping question. I didn't pick up on the slide, the marketing reinvestment of $120 million, is that front-weighted for the year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is it what?
componenttext: Is it what?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Is it front-loaded?
componenttext: Is it front-loaded?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me clarify. The $120 million, David, if you recall from Analyst Day, that $70 million of that was marketing and the rest in other investments within the business. And the marketing really is going to, as I tried to allude to, will ramp up through
componenttext: Yes, let me clarify. The $120 million, David, if you recall from Analyst Day, that $70 million of that was marketing and the rest in other investments within the business. And the marketing really is going to, as I tried to allude to, will ramp up through the remaining quarters. So marketing spending was up on a constant currency basis in Q1, but it will be up very significantly in Q2 and then in the remainder of the year, basically timed with the timing of our programs, the ideas and ready for the initiatives. So we're feeling good about the trajectory in the plans for going forward.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're going to see Heinz spend in marketing like you've never seen us before, and we're very excited about all of the launches and the brand support that is coming out. And in fact, we're going to show you a lot of that at the upcoming back-to-schoo
componenttext: Yes, you're going to see Heinz spend in marketing like you've never seen us before, and we're very excited about all of the launches and the brand support that is coming out. And in fact, we're going to show you a lot of that at the upcoming back-to-school conference. So get ready, it's on. Heinz is on the Olympics. We've done a number of things, so very exciting.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we fully expect to spend at least that $70 million of incremental marketing that we talked about in May.
componenttext: Yes. So we fully expect to spend at least that $70 million of incremental marketing that we talked about in May.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: The Europe division, you mentioned that conditions were tough there. Are conditions, in your opinion in terms of the consumer, getting worse there? And are you expecting even budgeting for increasingly difficult consumer environment through the fiscal yea
componenttext: The Europe division, you mentioned that conditions were tough there. Are conditions, in your opinion in terms of the consumer, getting worse there? And are you expecting even budgeting for increasingly difficult consumer environment through the fiscal year in that region?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, it's -- David, it's kind of interesting how Europe is sort of a tale of 2 cities for us. If you go to either end of the continent, we're performing extremely well. So Russia and the East in particular had a great quarter. We feel really good about the
componenttext: No, it's -- David, it's kind of interesting how Europe is sort of a tale of 2 cities for us. If you go to either end of the continent, we're performing extremely well. So Russia and the East in particular had a great quarter. We feel really good about the momentum in Russia both from a top line and a gross margin standpoint. And the U.K. business continues to be a fortress for us given the strength of our brand equities there and the power of the innovation and execution within the business. So at both ends of the continent, we feel very good about things. To your point, it's a tough market in the middle of the continent. Continental Europe and Italy, consumer confidence is low, unemployment is high. And so it's a challenging market there, and I think we continue to evolve our products and our packaging to meet that environment. And I'm really pleased that we got a good strong head start on driving the European agenda with what we're doing with Keystone, what we're doing with the supply chain consolidation.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Innovation Center.
componenttext: Innovation Center.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: With the Innovation Center, so lots of things going on to address it. So I'm not so sure that we expect things in the middle of the continent to get too much worse, but we're sure not expecting it to get better anytime soon.
componenttext: With the Innovation Center, so lots of things going on to address it. So I'm not so sure that we expect things in the middle of the continent to get too much worse, but we're sure not expecting it to get better anytime soon.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the profit growth that was high single digits organic, the story there is largely the productivity and the restructuring from last year flowing through? Or is that a significant push and that still that the promotion efficiency efforts that you're --
componenttext: And the profit growth that was high single digits organic, the story there is largely the productivity and the restructuring from last year flowing through? Or is that a significant push and that still that the promotion efficiency efforts that you're -- that's been ongoing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's all of the above. So we're certainly getting restructuring benefits that we had expected, so that's a good thing. We're continuing to drive productivity initiative this year, particularly value engineering. Strong organic top line growth in s
componenttext: I think it's all of the above. So we're certainly getting restructuring benefits that we had expected, so that's a good thing. We're continuing to drive productivity initiative this year, particularly value engineering. Strong organic top line growth in some of our markets is certainly helping out as well. And again, with regard to Europe in particular, it's driven at both ends of the continent.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason English with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason English with Goldman Sachs.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: First, a quick housekeeping item. Brazil, can you quantify the impact that had in both the top and bottom line this quarter, just the 1 month move?
componenttext: First, a quick housekeeping item. Brazil, can you quantify the impact that had in both the top and bottom line this quarter, just the 1 month move?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the 1 month was worth roughly $35 million on a gross basis. And keep in mind, though, that a lot of that was offset by the decisions we made in Long Fong and the exit of T.G.I.F. meals, but roughly $35 million at the top line. The bottom line is less
componenttext: Yes, the 1 month was worth roughly $35 million on a gross basis. And keep in mind, though, that a lot of that was offset by the decisions we made in Long Fong and the exit of T.G.I.F. meals, but roughly $35 million at the top line. The bottom line is less than $0.01, so basically immaterial.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then that's just because we're reinvesting in that market the profits back in to grow and capture the middle-class growth.
componenttext: Right. And then that's just because we're reinvesting in that market the profits back in to grow and capture the middle-class growth.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And a question on North America. Dave Woodward has been there for not too long, yes. I imagine he's still trying to get his feet firmly planted. Any early read on what we may expect to see differently coming out of that market with the new
componenttext: That's helpful. And a question on North America. Dave Woodward has been there for not too long, yes. I imagine he's still trying to get his feet firmly planted. Any early read on what we may expect to see differently coming out of that market with the new leadership?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Dave is bringing great energy and enthusiasm to the role and he's working to drive what we would call a demand-driven recovery. So I think he's focused on the big brands and you saw that we've exited a few of our smaller less advantaged brands, so
componenttext: I think Dave is bringing great energy and enthusiasm to the role and he's working to drive what we would call a demand-driven recovery. So I think he's focused on the big brands and you saw that we've exited a few of our smaller less advantaged brands, so we're really gearing the focus on those big brands. We're getting the price value offering correct across the portfolio. Once we do that, we're increasing the marketing support behind those key brands. And then undergirding it all, we're driving a strong productivity to provide some fuel for growth. So I think we're doing the right things. You saw that volume shares were up in 9  out of 12 categories, so we're pleased with that while our average price is up, so investing in the business, driving some innovation and we're -- I think there's work to be done. But we're pleased Dave's on the case.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And do you think you can still get to your mid single-digit constant currency profit growth guidance for the full year with some of those initiatives?
componenttext: And do you think you can still get to your mid single-digit constant currency profit growth guidance for the full year with some of those initiatives?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think all of those things that we've talked about are in our guidance for the full year, which what we're affirming today. So I guess to answer your question, yes.
componenttext: I think all of those things that we've talked about are in our guidance for the full year, which what we're affirming today. So I guess to answer your question, yes.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Driscoll of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Driscoll of Citi.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'd like to start off with the gross margin outlook. I think you guys had said that you expect a 50 to 100 basis point expansion on the year. The quarter was up something about 20 basis points. So can you bridge how the pacing goes? Ed, I think you even m
componenttext: I'd like to start off with the gross margin outlook. I think you guys had said that you expect a 50 to 100 basis point expansion on the year. The quarter was up something about 20 basis points. So can you bridge how the pacing goes? Ed, I think you even mentioned in your script about the dramatic expansions that go forward because of pricing and productivity. But can you guys just expand on this a little bit so folks can get a little comfort that these expansions are on track with your plan?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, David, let me hit that first and Ed can add some color. Our gross margin was largely in line with our plan in the first quarter. We do expect the year-on-year increase in gross margin to gain sequentially. I mean, that's really driven by 3 key t
componenttext: Yes. Yes, David, let me hit that first and Ed can add some color. Our gross margin was largely in line with our plan in the first quarter. We do expect the year-on-year increase in gross margin to gain sequentially. I mean, that's really driven by 3 key things. I think you'll see somewhat better pricing in the back half on a net price basis. We'll have a different and more favorable business unit and product mix as well. And we've got this heavy focus going on in terms of value engineering that combines with the restructuring programs and savings that we had from last year. So all of those things worked to our benefit. The other thing we're seeing, over time, we're seeing the gross margins improving in our newer businesses, in Quero in Brazil and Foodstar in China. As usual, when you buy these businesses, the gross margin tend to start out relatively low but the opportunity to drive those northward, we're certainly seeing that. And so we expect that to continue. The other thing I might add is that we're beginning to leverage the scale and efficiencies of our consolidated European supply chain hub, so we feel good about where we're going there. We've had our new global head of procurement, John Dickson, joined not too long ago and I think he's starting to make some traction. So net-net, we feel good about the levers and the trajectory as we look forward.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I'd follow up with a question on cost savings and input costs. The cost savings question, I believe this year, you're looking for total cost saves of $250 million. Can you just update that, is that still the number? Is it any better? And then w
componenttext: Okay. Then I'd follow up with a question on cost savings and input costs. The cost savings question, I believe this year, you're looking for total cost saves of $250 million. Can you just update that, is that still the number? Is it any better? And then what did you realize in the first quarter and how does the pacing of that go throughout the year? And then just a quick update on input cost inflation, how much is hedged and what's the rate of market inflation that you guys typically could? I know you said the quarter, but what's the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of productivity from particularly the supply chain, I think we're on or better than the target so far. And we believe we've had some opportunity there, and we'll see as the year goes along and we'll play that out. But productivity is running
componenttext: Yes, in terms of productivity from particularly the supply chain, I think we're on or better than the target so far. And we believe we've had some opportunity there, and we'll see as the year goes along and we'll play that out. But productivity is running according to plan or better. And in terms of market inflation, I think the market inflation estimates are still pretty much in line with what we had talked about at Analyst Day, and if I'm recalling right, that was around 4%.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you've seen a lot of inflation in a lot of commodities out there. And fortunately for us, we've locked in a good portion of our year. So the market inflation could be somewhere in the neighborhood of 4-plus, 4% to 5%, but that's highly depend
componenttext: Yes. I think you've seen a lot of inflation in a lot of commodities out there. And fortunately for us, we've locked in a good portion of our year. So the market inflation could be somewhere in the neighborhood of 4-plus, 4% to 5%, but that's highly dependent on several of these crops out there. The big impact, as Ed had mentioned previously, sweeteners and in particular, Indonesia. So palm sugars, it's very, very strong right now on pricing. So -- but the good news for us is that we have -- that will come in largely line with expectation because we have largely taken that off the table.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it depicts [indiscernible] guys have gone ahead as they saw things going up. And we're covered a bit more than we would normally be this time of year, and the way things are looking, that's really advantageous. I think also going back to the
componenttext: Yes, I think it depicts [indiscernible] guys have gone ahead as they saw things going up. And we're covered a bit more than we would normally be this time of year, and the way things are looking, that's really advantageous. I think also going back to the productivity issues that we were going through the major plant moves and that sort of thing last year, the guys -- the operations guys were focused on that. Now that they've got that running, what they're focused on is the normal type of productivity that's sort of been followed through a little bit that they can really focus on and really will start delivering benefits in the second half of the year on top of the productivity restructuring charges from last year.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's well put. And David, you've heard the headlines about corn prices because of the heat and drought and things like that. But to Meg's point, we are virtually all hedged on a lot of those key commodities. So we really are pretty confiden
componenttext: Yes, I think that's well put. And David, you've heard the headlines about corn prices because of the heat and drought and things like that. But to Meg's point, we are virtually all hedged on a lot of those key commodities. So we really are pretty confident in our outlook on the commodity costs.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, to your question on sculpting, back-half loaded.
componenttext: Yes, to your question on sculpting, back-half loaded.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney, Janney Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney, Janney Capital Markets.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I knew you covered this a little bit. I just want -- can you give me a detail about what are the 2 or 3 big factors that drive the swings in this tax rate? Because it's just you have a real look -- I mean, was -- is this consistent with what you thought c
componenttext: I knew you covered this a little bit. I just want -- can you give me a detail about what are the 2 or 3 big factors that drive the swings in this tax rate? Because it's just you have a real look -- I mean, was -- is this consistent with what you thought coming into the year the taxes would flow this way? And what causes them, the inter-quarter variations so much? And I'm just thinking how much of that laps into -- the structural stop that laps into fiscal '14 and '15 or stuff that is dependent on some of the factors, discrete to 2013?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: If you'll go back to last year, we had a similar discrete transaction in Q2. We were able to execute a similar transaction in Q1 of this year and we're planning for another one in the following quarter. Some tax planning initiatives are spread over evenly
componenttext: If you'll go back to last year, we had a similar discrete transaction in Q2. We were able to execute a similar transaction in Q1 of this year and we're planning for another one in the following quarter. Some tax planning initiatives are spread over evenly over quarters. And over the years, it's obviously very discrete, that the 2 that we're referring to here are discrete. Now what the tax guys are looking at is to continue to examine programs into the future years to try to keep that rate down in the low 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And we have the benefit this quarter. As we did last year 1Q, the U.K. again took its corporate tax rate down some 200 basis points, doing the right thing to incent businesses. And so we're very pleased with that. But you see the benefit of th
componenttext: Absolutely. And we have the benefit this quarter. As we did last year 1Q, the U.K. again took its corporate tax rate down some 200 basis points, doing the right thing to incent businesses. And so we're very pleased with that. But you see the benefit of that because that has a bit of a retroactive impact and a one-time big benefit in the quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And I think that's another advantage of our having most of our sales overseas. These foreign tax opportunity did present themselves and we have a team that's scaling the world to look for taking advantage of that.
componenttext: And I think that's another advantage of our having most of our sales overseas. These foreign tax opportunity did present themselves and we have a team that's scaling the world to look for taking advantage of that.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's -- the key point is given our significant global mix of sales in international, that allows us a lot more tax planning opportunities in those foreign jurisdictions, and frankly, the foreign jurisdiction seem to understand that a lower
componenttext: Yes, I think that's -- the key point is given our significant global mix of sales in international, that allows us a lot more tax planning opportunities in those foreign jurisdictions, and frankly, the foreign jurisdiction seem to understand that a lower tax rate is a good thing for their economy. So that's where they're moving to do. To your other points, we constantly look for opportunities to drive down the tax rate. Over the long term, you saw that we had a low tax rate in the low 20s last year. We expect it to be this year and we're certainly working on initiatives to continue that going forward in the future years now. We'll talk more about that as the year goes along, but that is certainly the expectation and the plan that we would continue driving those kinds of numbers.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Remember, Heinz is 2/3 international or non-U.S. sales, so we're going to -- our tax rate will vary accordingly.
componenttext: Remember, Heinz is 2/3 international or non-U.S. sales, so we're going to -- our tax rate will vary accordingly.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. By the way, I wish that the timing of these things was perfectly predictable and even through the quarters, but that's just not the reality of the way taxes work.
componenttext: Yes. By the way, I wish that the timing of these things was perfectly predictable and even through the quarters, but that's just not the reality of the way taxes work.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Thilo Wrede of Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Thilo Wrede of Jefferies & Company.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is actually Brian on for Thilo. Just -- and most of my questions have been answered, but just wanted to touch on the Dip & Squeeze patent lawsuit. Is there any product risk there? Is there any update on what's going on there?
componenttext: This is actually Brian on for Thilo. Just -- and most of my questions have been answered, but just wanted to touch on the Dip & Squeeze patent lawsuit. Is there any product risk there? Is there any update on what's going on there?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: We view that as a frivolous situation, and we will be defending it rigorously and we're not overly worried about it.
componenttext: We view that as a frivolous situation, and we will be defending it rigorously and we're not overly worried about it.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Goldman, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Goldman, JPMorgan.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So to follow up on the tax rate, the implication there, it sounds like if you're talking about, I don't know, 12%, 13% for the second quarter, if I'm hearing the low double-digit number right, to get to about a 23% number for the year, you have to do abou
componenttext: So to follow up on the tax rate, the implication there, it sounds like if you're talking about, I don't know, 12%, 13% for the second quarter, if I'm hearing the low double-digit number right, to get to about a 23% number for the year, you have to do about 30% tax rate in the back half of the year. I just want to make sure that math is correct.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: It'll be upper 20s.
componenttext: It'll be upper 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Upper 20s.
componenttext: Upper 20s.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right, but the tax guidance for the year is flat, and last year was 21.7%. So -- okay?
componenttext: Right, but the tax guidance for the year is flat, and last year was 21.7%. So -- okay?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then the question I have, as a follow-up to that, would be a lot -- there's a lot of companies out there now that have a lot of international sales. You certainly are in that group and you've done a great job building you
componenttext: Okay, got it. That's helpful. And then the question I have, as a follow-up to that, would be a lot -- there's a lot of companies out there now that have a lot of international sales. You certainly are in that group and you've done a great job building your global portfolio to get there, but not every company is able to define these discrete transactions, as you call them, as often as you do. And I think the credit goes to your tax department genuinely for finding them, but I'm curious what do you credit that to? What are you able to do that without disparaging other companies that may be other companies aren't able to find, it does seem like you're able to get lower taxes than other companies on an average basis, even other companies that may have even more of international exposure that you do. So I'm just curious if you can help me understand that a little bit.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have a team downstairs that is very focused on it. In addition, we have a lot of outsiders that come in and present opportunities. We -- when we go into the various countries, we try to get very familiar with what they launch, what the opportun
componenttext: I mean, we have a team downstairs that is very focused on it. In addition, we have a lot of outsiders that come in and present opportunities. We -- when we go into the various countries, we try to get very familiar with what they launch, what the opportunities are. We engage local tax experts and we take it very seriously. It is an opportunity when you're -- when you've got the geographic stance that we have to take advantage of that. So most of these ideas are not internally generated. We listen attentively to other people with ideas, see if they work with our portfolio and try to capitalize on them the best we can, so a very active team.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I suspect our business unit mix is an advantage for us. But I think at the end of the day, we have a great tax team that does exceptionally good work.
componenttext: Yes, I suspect our business unit mix is an advantage for us. But I think at the end of the day, we have a great tax team that does exceptionally good work.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And very quickly, Meg, when you talk about expecting constant currency EPS growth of about 10%, what's the base on that? There've been some divestitures, some SKU rationalizations, is it the $0.81 base? Or how do we look at that from 2Q '12?
componenttext: And very quickly, Meg, when you talk about expecting constant currency EPS growth of about 10%, what's the base on that? There've been some divestitures, some SKU rationalizations, is it the $0.81 base? Or how do we look at that from 2Q '12?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is based off the $0.81 roughly, yes.
componenttext: Yes, it is based off the $0.81 roughly, yes.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger, Morgan Stanley.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to get your thoughts on the pricing and promotional environment in North America, how you characterize things at the moment. Are you feeling any more or less confident than you were 3 months ago in being able to achieve whatever level of
componenttext: So I just wanted to get your thoughts on the pricing and promotional environment in North America, how you characterize things at the moment. Are you feeling any more or less confident than you were 3 months ago in being able to achieve whatever level of pricing is -- was embedded in your initial fiscal '13 plan? And should we consider the level of pricing we saw in North America in Q1 to be sort of reflective of what you're looking for, for the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Matt, it's -- I mean, to your point, it's a competitive world out there and there's no doubt about it in the developed markets including the U.S. are certainly challenged. But I think it's all about balance. This isn't -- it isn't a black-and-white thing
componenttext: Matt, it's -- I mean, to your point, it's a competitive world out there and there's no doubt about it in the developed markets including the U.S. are certainly challenged. But I think it's all about balance. This isn't -- it isn't a black-and-white thing and it varies by category and it varies by country. So it goes business-to-business, and we're trying to be very nuanced in our approach. So list pricing actions, in some cases, are not in the cards. On the flip side of that, we have driven, I think, very effectively against making our promotion spending more efficient and more effective, in many cases, both for us and for our trade customers. So I think Dave Moran has been doing a nice job with his team over in Europe on that. Dave Woodward certainly is focused in that arena. We're focused on it in Australia as well. So I'd say it's a difficult environment, but we're -- I think, we've got the tools and the knowledge to be more nuanced and more effective at it than what we would've been in the past. And then fundamentally, you probably got more pricing power in Emerging Markets just based on the fragmented trade environment and the more fragmented competitive set we see in those markets. So we believe we're on track to our plans for pricing, but it's certainly not an easy environment.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as always, the consumer is going to pay for what they perceive to be value, and we have to get that value equation right. In some cases, that means prices go up. In some cases, that means we get a little more competitive. And the key is the i
componenttext: Yes, I think as always, the consumer is going to pay for what they perceive to be value, and we have to get that value equation right. In some cases, that means prices go up. In some cases, that means we get a little more competitive. And the key is the innovations, the brand support driving the consumer to the shelf, doing all the right things by the brand. And I know Dave Woodward and the North American team is striving for this long-term sustainable growth in their business, so stay tuned.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a very quick housekeeping, apologies if I missed this, but have -- can you provide any sort of updated FX guidance either on the sales or EPS line for the full year?
componenttext: Okay. And a very quick housekeeping, apologies if I missed this, but have -- can you provide any sort of updated FX guidance either on the sales or EPS line for the full year?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think when we talked to you guys in May, we had expected that the FX would be an impact of about $0.06 for the full year. You saw that we got hit with $0.04 just in Q1 alone. If recollection serves me correctly, if the rates stayed around where they are
componenttext: I think when we talked to you guys in May, we had expected that the FX would be an impact of about $0.06 for the full year. You saw that we got hit with $0.04 just in Q1 alone. If recollection serves me correctly, if the rates stayed around where they are now, you might see another $0.05 over that $0.06 that we're talking about, another $0.04 to $0.05. Having said that, we tend not to really adjust our outlook for Forex this early in the year because you're starting to see a lot of volatility. And frankly, over the recent days, we're seeing some of the currency rates move slightly in our favor. So it's hard to say, it's early in the year yet, but I think there's probably another $0.04 to $0.05 if nothing changed on currency for the full year.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Dickerson, Consumer Edge.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Dickerson, Consumer Edge.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of quick questions for you. I guess the first is just on cash. I know you said, I think you put in the prepared remarks and discussed that you have cash $1 billion-plus now. I know it could be very small change, but before you were saying
componenttext: So just a couple of quick questions for you. I guess the first is just on cash. I know you said, I think you put in the prepared remarks and discussed that you have cash $1 billion-plus now. I know it could be very small change, but before you were saying I think $1.1 billion. And in line with that, I also solved I guess the cash balances at the end of the year was a little bit higher than we're seeing in Q1. So I was wondering if you could just kind of provide a little color as to why there should be incrementally more pressure on operating free cash flow.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me be clear. We didn't consciously change anything in our guidance. So what we said in May, that is our outlook for cash flow. I think Q1 was impacted by 3 things, as Ed alluded to. First, we had the carryover productivity spending from the restr
componenttext: Yes, let me be clear. We didn't consciously change anything in our guidance. So what we said in May, that is our outlook for cash flow. I think Q1 was impacted by 3 things, as Ed alluded to. First, we had the carryover productivity spending from the restructuring activities last year. That was $40-some million, which took our cash negative for the quarter. Capital spending was up a bit, and then there was some timing of receivable securitizations. But if you remember, we are a very back-half-oriented company. If you go back over the history of Heinz over the last 10 years, given the crop cycles in the northern hemisphere, we tend to be back-half-loaded in terms of cash flow. So we feel like we're on track for that. We've got a strong history of delivering cash. So we're tracking to it. As always, a lot of hard work to be done but we're on track. Your other question was on cash balance? Refresh my memory, Rob, what...

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: You're right. That's [indiscernible] to 1Q, but that's just we're buying inventories as crops are coming in, we're setting up for the year, so that's -- and the carryover productivity cash, so that's normal.
componenttext: You're right. That's [indiscernible] to 1Q, but that's just we're buying inventories as crops are coming in, we're setting up for the year, so that's -- and the carryover productivity cash, so that's normal.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's normal cyclicality.
componenttext: That's normal cyclicality.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then I guess the second question is just a bit broader is you pre-released yesterday, EPS constant currency is up a little over 15%. You're saying, I guess, for Q2 that you expecting a low double-digit tax rate, but then for the full ye
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then I guess the second question is just a bit broader is you pre-released yesterday, EPS constant currency is up a little over 15%. You're saying, I guess, for Q2 that you expecting a low double-digit tax rate, but then for the full year, you expect similar to what you guided to at the Investor Day. So that should be in line going up in the back half. It sounds like there's a little bit more investment coming in Q2 and really in the back half. So if you're not increasing guidance on constant currency from $0.05 to $0.08 even though you did 15% in Q1 and then Q2 would seem like you would have to be a little bit higher than guidance, too, just because of the tax rate again, is it -- is what -- are you just playing it safe in Q1 because it's early in the fiscal year? Or is what we should be expecting and modeling is basically a deceleration of EPS growth into the back half of the fiscal year really because the tax rate rolls off?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind 2 things, that first, the tax rate does get higher in the back half, no doubt about that. So that's largely a timing issue. But we are investing heavily in the business in the back half of the year. So some of that $120 million investme
componenttext: Well, keep in mind 2 things, that first, the tax rate does get higher in the back half, no doubt about that. So that's largely a timing issue. But we are investing heavily in the business in the back half of the year. So some of that $120 million investment is more back-half loaded than front half just given the timing of the initiatives. So it's a combination of investment and then the timing of tax. But I think look back at our history, we've always shied away from moving guidance in the first -- our outlook in the first quarter. It's still early yet in the year. We'll see how things continue to progress. It's a volatile world out there, so I think we'll talk to you further on that in the end of Q2. But as we say, we have a history of trying to invest in the business to make sure that our growth is sustainable over the long term.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as your modeling go get ahead as you please. This is a company that focuses on its targets. We've got a pretty broad target, $3.52 to $3.62 constant currency guidance. And when the company tends to exceed, we tend to reinvest to drive sustainable
componenttext: Sure. So as your modeling go get ahead as you please. This is a company that focuses on its targets. We've got a pretty broad target, $3.52 to $3.62 constant currency guidance. And when the company tends to exceed, we tend to reinvest to drive sustainable growth. So we've got a lot of very strong investments this year. And -- but to Art's point, it's the first quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right, certainly.
componenttext: Right, certainly.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Lazar, Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Lazar, Barclays.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up quickly on I think it was Ed's comment where he'd mentioned that in frozen, I think both volume and price were contributors in the quarter. Just want to make sure I have that right, and if I do, when was sort of the last time yo
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up quickly on I think it was Ed's comment where he'd mentioned that in frozen, I think both volume and price were contributors in the quarter. Just want to make sure I have that right, and if I do, when was sort of the last time you had that at combination of that balance, if you will, in the frozen space? And was there anything in this quarter in particular that was either one-off about that, that I shouldn't expect that type of better balance going forward through the year, whether it's promotionally-oriented or what have yours or are we just getting back to a better balance given some of the changes in the price points and things that you're doing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: You did hear right, that is what I said. When the last time that occurred, I can't tell you offhand.
componenttext: You did hear right, that is what I said. When the last time that occurred, I can't tell you offhand.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's been a while, Andrew. There's a lot of discipline, there's been a lot of hard work by the brand team, doing the right thing on the shelf, a lot of great innovation that's out there. There are so many nuances in the Nielsen data that we know you can't
componenttext: It's been a while, Andrew. There's a lot of discipline, there's been a lot of hard work by the brand team, doing the right thing on the shelf, a lot of great innovation that's out there. There are so many nuances in the Nielsen data that we know you can't see. The main thing I would point out to you is Nielsen data is cash register ring [ph]. And so if the retailer makes some adjustments to their margin levels, that will reflect in Nielsen data. You think it's us, but it's not us. So Heinz is doing the right thing. The frozen team's working hard, the innovation's thriving. But to your point, we haven't seen that balance. I'll have to go back, I don't have -- it's one of the factoids I don't have with me. You stumped me. But we'll go back and look for that. But kudos to the North American frozen team, they're working really hard.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think, Andrew, the -- yes, to that point, we're pleased that both frozen and ambient were up. Ambient was up a bit more than frozen, but frozen being up nonetheless, I think part of that is that we continue to focus the portfolio on our bigger brands. A
componenttext: I think, Andrew, the -- yes, to that point, we're pleased that both frozen and ambient were up. Ambient was up a bit more than frozen, but frozen being up nonetheless, I think part of that is that we continue to focus the portfolio on our bigger brands. And so this is all about investing behind the core brands, the power brands that we can get some real bang from the profit [ph]. And I'd -- over time, I'd like to continue that because that's where I think the growth can be driven quite successfully.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And also keep in mind that the Long Fong business that we discussed was actually a headwind to the frozen volumes down this quarter.
componenttext: And also keep in mind that the Long Fong business that we discussed was actually a headwind to the frozen volumes down this quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. Last thing, and it's immediately more qualitative, but I think also you -- in addition to a change at the top of NACP, you've also had a fairly recent change in head of sales there with John Hans and trying to get a sense of perhaps what's kind of
componenttext: Right. Last thing, and it's immediately more qualitative, but I think also you -- in addition to a change at the top of NACP, you've also had a fairly recent change in head of sales there with John Hans and trying to get a sense of perhaps what's kind of most clear and present in terms of opportunities that you get a sense coming from him as well.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think David's bringing high level of energies plugged in and he's got a track record of strong innovation and doing some great things in the U.K. We have every expectation that he'll do that in the U.S. as well. And so -- but it's his early days and imp
componenttext: I think David's bringing high level of energies plugged in and he's got a track record of strong innovation and doing some great things in the U.K. We have every expectation that he'll do that in the U.S. as well. And so -- but it's his early days and implementing changes that he'll continue to figure out exactly what he wants to do and we'll keep you posted.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think John is very excited about the emerging channels. There's been a lot of work that's been done, our alternate channels if you will, by the North American team, the U.S. team. And so he's really embracing that and the opportunity that's present
componenttext: Yes, I think John is very excited about the emerging channels. There's been a lot of work that's been done, our alternate channels if you will, by the North American team, the U.S. team. And so he's really embracing that and the opportunity that's present for Heinz because that's not an area we have focused historically.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. And keep in mind, John came out of the U.S. business a few years ago and he was one of the guys who was instrumental in kicking off the trade promotion reduction program that we've talked about at USCP for a number of years.
componenttext: Yes. And keep in mind, John came out of the U.S. business a few years ago and he was one of the guys who was instrumental in kicking off the trade promotion reduction program that we've talked about at USCP for a number of years.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: That discipline and rigor. So it's to welcome John back to the U.S., and a lot of good initiatives underway.
componenttext: That discipline and rigor. So it's to welcome John back to the U.S., and a lot of good initiatives underway.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow, Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow, Crédit Suisse.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess my -- we did some work on operating income growth trends in the packaged food industry, and I'm sure you've seen this, too. But Heinz's income growth has only been, by our math, about 10% over the last 5 years when I strip out acquisitions. The gr
componenttext: I guess my -- we did some work on operating income growth trends in the packaged food industry, and I'm sure you've seen this, too. But Heinz's income growth has only been, by our math, about 10% over the last 5 years when I strip out acquisitions. The group is 28%. And I guess this is another quarter where operating income is flat, albeit there's a currency hit. And as I look at the guidance for the rest of the year, it doesn't look like operating income is going to be a major driver of earnings growth. And it's what I use in my models to do my valuation, and I think it encompasses a lot of what drives value. I'm just wondering internally, how important is the operating income growth to executive compensation. And when you look at your performance versus your peer group, are you seeing the same thing?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob, operating income growth is a key element of our compensation for all of our executives that run businesses. So yes, there is no lack of focus on it. I can't recognize the operating income numbers that you're talking about. Certainly, there's For
componenttext: Yes, Rob, operating income growth is a key element of our compensation for all of our executives that run businesses. So yes, there is no lack of focus on it. I can't recognize the operating income numbers that you're talking about. Certainly, there's Forex noise in there. There's divestiture noise in there.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Investment.
componenttext: Investment.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: And investment in the business. So I think all of those things play in, and we may need to compare notes on that front. But operating income is a key focus for us. And frankly, even with strong investment this year, we expect very solid operating income g
componenttext: And investment in the business. So I think all of those things play in, and we may need to compare notes on that front. But operating income is a key focus for us. And frankly, even with strong investment this year, we expect very solid operating income growth.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. Rob, I saw -- we saw your note come through and I just haven't had the time to focus on it yet. A, I think the number is understated. We'll get with you on it and see if we can't figure out. But b, understand that this is a company that's investing,
componenttext: Yes. Rob, I saw -- we saw your note come through and I just haven't had the time to focus on it yet. A, I think the number is understated. We'll get with you on it and see if we can't figure out. But b, understand that this is a company that's investing, and remember that Keystone has been gearing up over the last 5 years. And we've got -- we've been spending to really get highly efficient and leverage the scale of this organization. We have tremendous productivity coming in the coming years from Keystone alone, but it is a key goal of this organization to get our margins in that top tier, and we're going to go after it. So I saw that come through, but we'll be happy to work with you and narrow that down for you, help you out.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll show you what -- how I came to it. But here's another challenge for you guys. I've heard reinvestment a lot today and certainly at the Analyst Day, too. But then I look at the reshaping of the portfolio like the exit of T.G.I. Friday's, exit of Bosto
componenttext: I'll show you what -- how I came to it. But here's another challenge for you guys. I've heard reinvestment a lot today and certainly at the Analyst Day, too. But then I look at the reshaping of the portfolio like the exit of T.G.I. Friday's, exit of Boston Market, exit of -- streamlining Long Fong. These are areas where a few years ago, there was significant investment in those projects. So have you -- I guess that's my challenge. It's like do you feel like this amount of reinvestment that you're doing now, we're not going to look back 3 years forward and say we have to streamline again?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. I think, Rob, we're getting focused on those core Top 15 brands so we're really trying to focus where the biggest payback is. But I mean, to your point, over time the world changes and the reality has changed. Consumer traits change. Industry trends c
componenttext: No. I think, Rob, we're getting focused on those core Top 15 brands so we're really trying to focus where the biggest payback is. But I mean, to your point, over time the world changes and the reality has changed. Consumer traits change. Industry trends change. We will always try to be out front of those trends and those changes so that we're not getting dragged along behind trends. We're anticipating and we're getting down in front of them. We think those are the right things to do to continue to strengthen the portfolio. The investments are going behind our biggest brands, not some of these smaller brands. And I think one of the key statistics to keep an eye on or metrics is that percent of our total sales that are in those Top 15 brands, because those are the big powerhouse brands that I think have the leverage and the scale and the brand position to win. And so more and more, if we can focus the portfolio on those brands and then focus our resources, marketing and otherwise, on those, I think it's the right thing to do. But we're going to continue to evolve and adjust with the world that we're faced with.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And we've been talking to shareholders over the last several weeks and months frankly, who have actually praised us for moving quickly and making decisions. So we're trying some new things, and if they work, we continue to support them. If the
componenttext: Absolutely. And we've been talking to shareholders over the last several weeks and months frankly, who have actually praised us for moving quickly and making decisions. So we're trying some new things, and if they work, we continue to support them. If they don't, we make our move and we shift those dollars and reallocate them. And so I think Heinz is allocating its capital and its marketing dollars well, and the investment in systems is mandatory. It's something we have to do. As you know, we don't have a single ERP system where we can consolidate our global world, and that makes our world more difficult. And we've got to get that inefficiency out, so that spend is necessary. Regarding other investment spend, we evaluate. We're highly disciplined. And as you know, Bill thinks this industry overspends in given areas and he's going to make sure that we're getting a return for this money. And if we're not, he's going to -- he'll pull it and he'll move it elsewhere.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me ask you just 2 quick modeling questions. One is the Venezuela, how much of a drag if that on fiscal '13 compared to what happened last year? And then lastly, marketing spend, you say you're going to be up $70 million. Quantitatively, is it go
componenttext: Okay. Let me ask you just 2 quick modeling questions. One is the Venezuela, how much of a drag if that on fiscal '13 compared to what happened last year? And then lastly, marketing spend, you say you're going to be up $70 million. Quantitatively, is it going to look a little bit less because of currency?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me say something about Venezuela first. I mean Venezuela was down in the first quarter, as I recall, both sales and profit-wise. You've got an environment there that's a little bit up in the air. They've got a big election coming up in October, and I
componenttext: Let me say something about Venezuela first. I mean Venezuela was down in the first quarter, as I recall, both sales and profit-wise. You've got an environment there that's a little bit up in the air. They've got a big election coming up in October, and I think consumers are sort of sitting back and waiting to see how things trend. So that may stabilize as we go forward. Venezuela is not a big business for us, so it's not a huge impact, but it's not -- yes, and it certainly didn't help in Q1. In terms of the marketing spend, on a constant currency basis, we've talked about at least $70 million. To the extent that currency moves in the other direction, it could moderate from there. But I'll tell you, I suspect that we're going to have enough great ideas and enough good brand initiatives that we may go past that $70 million, we'll see.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. So when I look at I think $460 million of advertising expense or marketing expense in fiscal '12, should it look more like $530 million for fiscal '13 when it's all said and done?
componenttext: Okay. So when I look at I think $460 million of advertising expense or marketing expense in fiscal '12, should it look more like $530 million for fiscal '13 when it's all said and done?

componenttextpreview: On a constant currency basis?
componenttext: On a constant currency basis?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, that would be right.
componenttext: Yes, yes, that would be right.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin, Davenport.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin, Davenport.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask one more thing about M&A opportunities. Any change in the pipeline, time line expectations for opportunities for M&A either domestically or internationally?
componenttext: I just wanted to ask one more thing about M&A opportunities. Any change in the pipeline, time line expectations for opportunities for M&A either domestically or internationally?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, good question. We're working on -- it is a very active pipeline. We've got a lot going on, on that front. And frankly, we're thrilled with the performance of our 2 most recent acquisitions in Quero and Foodstar, so we'd love to get more just like th
componenttext: Well, good question. We're working on -- it is a very active pipeline. We've got a lot going on, on that front. And frankly, we're thrilled with the performance of our 2 most recent acquisitions in Quero and Foodstar, so we'd love to get more just like them. Obviously, I can't speak about specific opportunities, but there's a number of them that we're working. The pipeline is very full. We -- especially in Emerging Markets, we tend to be very thorough and patient to ensure that we end up with the right strategic fit and we don't overpay. So we're excited about it. We're working on things. We'll keep you posted. We continue to work and focus on Emerging Markets and then also in our -- really 2 of our core categories, Ketchup & Sauces and Infant/Nutrition. But lots going on, and again, we'll keep you posted as time unfolds.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's frustrating you can't get them across the line. These are relationships and negotiations, but we're not going to rush it. We're going to do the right thing.All right. Well, we look forward to seeing many of you next week at the Barclays Back-t
componenttext:
Yes, it's frustrating you can't get them across the line. These are relationships and negotiations, but we're not going to rush it. We're going to do the right thing.
All right. Well, we look forward to seeing many of you next week at the Barclays Back-to-School Conference in Boston, where Art will present Wednesday, September 5. The time slot is now 9:45 a.m. And as always, Mary Ann and I will be around today to answer any follow-up questions. The whole IR team, the mainline is (412) 456-6020. Have a  great day.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Aug 29, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks.
componenttext: Thanks.
