headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, my name is Rachel and I'm your conference coordinator for today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the H.J. Heinz Company Fiscal Year 2013 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded at the request of H.J
componenttext:
Good morning, my name is Rachel and I'm your conference coordinator for today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the H.J. Heinz Company Fiscal Year 2013 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded at the request of H.J. Heinz Company. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the call over to Meg Nollen, Senior Vice President of Strategy and Investor Relations. Ms. Nollen, you may begin your conference.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rachel, and good morning. I'd like to welcome, everyone to our conference call and webcast. Copies of the slides used in today's presentation are available on our website at heinz.com. Joining me on today's call are Bill Johnson, Chairman, Pres
componenttext:
Thank you, Rachel, and good morning. I'd like to welcome, everyone to our conference call and webcast. Copies of the slides used in today's presentation are available on our website at heinz.com. Joining me on today's call are Bill Johnson, Chairman, President and CEO; Art Winkleblack, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Ed McMenamin, Senior Vice President, Finance will join us for Q&A.
Before we begin with our prepared remarks, please refer to the forward-looking statement currently displayed. This is also available in this morning's earnings release and in our most recent SEC filings.
To summarize, during our presentation, we may make forward-looking statements about our business that are intended to assist you in understanding the company and its results. We ask you to refer to our April 29, 2012 Form 10-K and today's press release, which list some of the factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in these statements. Heinz undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by securities laws.
We may also use non-GAAP financial measures in our presentation as the company believes such measures allow for consistent period-to-period comparison of the business. The most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures are available in the company's earnings release today and on our website at heinz.com.
Our complete financial highlights pages or stat pages are available on the Investor Relations section of heinz.com towards the bottom of the page. Please note we plan to file our first quarter 10-Q later today.
Finally, we'd like to request that you limit your questions during the Q&A session to one single-part question in order to ensure adequate time for all of who wish to participate and to ensure we end the call timely.
Now with the formalities out of the way, let me turn over to Bill Johnson. Bill?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Meg. And good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to join you today to discuss our second quarter results, the company's full year outlook and my perspective on the global environment. Starting with the second quarter, Heinz Liberty EPS of $0.90 fro
componenttext:
Thank you, Meg. And good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to join you today to discuss our second quarter results, the company's full year outlook and my perspective on the global environment. Starting with the second quarter, Heinz Liberty EPS of $0.90 from continuing operations with organic sales growth of between 3% and 4%, our 30th consecutive quarter of organic top line growth. These results reflect a nice balance between volume and pricing, and strengthen our 3 engines of growth: Emerging Markets, Global Ketchup and our Top 15 Brands. Second quarter earnings benefited from a favorable effective tax rate that we leveraged to significantly increase investment in marketing and global capabilities to drive further growth. Importantly, we increased marketing spend by over 13% in the quarter on a constant currency basis with a particularly large increase in North America where I am encouraged by our recent momentum. We're also continuing to ramp up investments behind enhanced Emerging Markets capabilities and our global SAP implementation. 
Consistent with our efforts to improve global capabilities and enhanced innovation, I am pleased to announce that we are nearing the completion of our European innovation and quality center in The Netherlands, which will open shortly. Our business results as I said a moment ago were again led by our trio of growth engines: Emerging Markets, Global Ketchup and our Top 15 Brands. Emerging Markets delivered organic sales growth of more than 13% and would have been up well over 14% if it were not for the impact of the land Long Fong downsizing. Global Ketchup grew 5%. And our Top 15 Brands grew almost 5% despite the exit from T.G.I.F. meals, which reduced organic sales by almost 90 basis points. 
Emerging market results were led by Brazil, reflecting the strength of the Quero brands of tomatoes sauces, ketchup and vegetables, and the launch of Heinz tomato paste, and China behind the success of Foodstar. The recently acquired businesses have performed well been our initial expectations and both appear to have considerable upside.
Indonesia, Russia, Mexico and the Middle East also grew quite strongly in the quarter. Taking a closer look at Brazil and China, Brazil delivered organic sales growth of 33% in the quarter, but improved value share is in a number of categories, including Ketchup, pasta sauces and vegetables. Importantly, we have commenced manufacturing Heinz tomato paste in Brazil, and will begin producing Heinz Ketchup locally next month to accelerate its distribution and availability. 
In China, our Ketchup condiments and sauces business delivered strong organic growth of around 20% driven by the momentum of our Master, Long Fong and Heinz brands. Our China's our strategy is focused on these 3 core brands with significant growth potential as we continue to expand across the country. This will be enhanced upon the completion of the Shanghai factory, which will increase our source bottling capacity in China by nearly 2/3 to support continued growth in the world's largest soy sauce market. Overall, Emerging Markets generated 23% in the company sales in the quarter. And given our success in Brazil, Russia and China in particular, we are aggressively evaluating both organic and M&A growth initiatives in these markets.
Our second growth engine, Global Ketchup, also performed well in the quarter led by solid sales increases in the U.S., Brazil and Russia. We still have considerable opportunity in Ketchup, condiments and sauces, which is a category now approaching 50% of total Heinz sales. We are focused in driving usage and share in our core casing and business in developed markets, while simultaneously introducing millions of new middle class consumers in Emerging Markets to Heinz Ketchup in our core soy sauce brands.
Marketing and M&A initiatives are being increasingly directed against large opportunity in condiments and sauces where we have proven we have a clear right to win. And finally, our Top 15 Brands delivered strong organic sales growth of 4.6% in the quarter, led by Heinz, Quero and ABC despite the aforementioned exit from T.G.I.F. meals. Notably, we have seen improvement in our U.S. business with around 65% of our consumer product portfolio now growing volume share. The share improvement reflects increased brand investments and better execution. 
As promised, we are taking significant action to return the U.S. profitable growth and we'll continue to do so. We have made progress on our Ore-Ida and Classico well we have a choice of value propositions while increasing market and innovation between both brands.
We are taking similar action to drive Heinz Ketchup growth in the U.S. and I am pleased with the response to our outreach in the Hispanic community, where we are building penetration and travel through multilingual advertising more affordable packaging like the $0.99 pouch. We continue to build excitement around our flagship products with new varieties like balsamic ketchup and Jalapeño ketchup, which we are launching on cyber Monday through a Facebook campaign. Additionally, to leverage our strong brand equity and reduce packaging material, we are also introducing PET ketchup bottles that are inspired by our iconic 14-ounce glass bottles. They're redesigned models are being offered in the recent sizes, which you will see on the shelves soon. This is a very clever refresh of our flagship Ketchup product that will enhance our merchandising and marketing utilities.
The U.S. team has also begun to make progress in all channels like drug and dollar stores to improve destroy more targeted product offerings aimed at value consumers. It's important to note that our efforts to strengthen and improve our largest and most important business are being lead by a significantly upgraded management team featuring a number of new appointments. I am pleased to announce once again Heinz is been ranked #1 in overall customer satisfaction among food manufacturers in the 2012 American Customer Satisfaction Index. Heinz led all food manufacturers for the 13th consecutive year.
Europe had somewhat more difficult quarter than it experienced recently. However, on a relative basis our results compared favorably to our peers primarily due to strengthened U.K. behind solid innovation and great results in soup and the strength of our Russian business. In short we are holding our own in Europe despite an extremely challenging economic environment that they will discuss in a minute.
Finally I want to comment on 1 other second quarter highlight. This time a year ago, we were discussing challenges based by our U.S. Foodservice and Australian businesses and so they, I am pleased a device of that the actions we took over the past year have significantly improved the results from these 2 businesses.
Our second quarter results keep Heinz on tract to deliver our previously announced full year outlook for sales and profit. The full year we expect at least 4% organic sales growth in line with our results for the first 6 months. Constant currency EPS growth of 5% to 8% on a continuing operations basis, excluding special items in fiscal 2012, and strong operating free cash flow of $1 billion plus.
As a result, we are reaffirming our constant currency EPS outlook of $3.52 to $3.62. 
Before I turn the call over to Art, I want to share my perspective on the global economy and trends in consumer behavior. Obviously we are carefully monitoring the Eurozone crisis like our industry peers and we're working to assess whether the current market dislocations are of a temporary nature or systemically long term. We are seeing signs of European consumers in general are altering their food shopping and dining habits as the continent struggles with the debt crisis, steep unemployment and a variety of austerity and tax regimes. Like their U.S. counterparts, they are adapting to new economic realities and have developed a strong value mindset as result.
I have challenged our European businesses to see this as an opportunity rather than a rollback and believe we will put it the resiliently and successfully adapt to the economic trends and new consumer behavior in their markets. Here in the U.S., I have seen some signs of modest economic recovery and improving consumer confidence all although there's still great uncertainty in the fiscal cliff.
I don't expect robust economy growth in the U.S. in 2013, but I am encouraged by the progress in our U.S. businesses as we invest in our leading brands to drive growth. We need to remind ourselves that we saw staple products that enhance the foods that people enjoy everyday and we can successfully adapt to the new value orientation that we're a bit more flexible and nimble in our thinking.
I am still very bullish about the growth in Emerging Markets where Heinz has grown a the robust 16% rate year-to-date. Importantly, we are redeploying talent and investment behind our mercy market businesses and aggressively searching for new opportunities, while maintaining an appropriate level of investment in our key developed markets.
To win in this challenging environment, Heinz is focusing its severable for admitting the consumers changing needs, accelerating innovation across our brands and delivering even greater value for customers. With strong brands and balanced global portfolio, I believe that we are as well positioned to deliver to continue growth in the global economy as anyone. The economy remains challenging to say the least.
Our strategic continues to be focused on the long-term price of a significantly larger Emerging Markets business and global leadership in the very profitable Ketchup, condiments and sauces category. Reflecting our focus on driving global growth and shareholder value, I am pleased to announce that, Chief Operating Officer and emergent markets in South Pacific has been appointed to the Heinz Board of Directors. As the COO responsible for the fastest-growing markets, Frank will bring strong understanding of consumer trends and extensive as Rick S&P implementation experience our broad. In summary, our company remains focused on operating discipline, appropriate investment levels and profitable growth. And I believe we have the brands, the businesses, the talent and the strategy to enhance shareholder value. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Art and we'll be back later for your Q&A.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Today I'll take you through our Q2 results, provide a brief update on the first half and then discuss our expectations for the second half of the fiscal year. For the quarter, we achieved double-digit EPS g
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Today I'll take you through our Q2 results, provide a brief update on the first half and then discuss our expectations for the second half of the fiscal year. For the quarter, we achieved double-digit EPS growth from all angles. First, on a continuing operations basis, excluding prior year special items, results increased 11% to $0.90, and excluding the $0.02 negative impact from foreign exchange, EPS increased 14%.
On a total company reported basis, the EPS increased increase was even stronger, up 23%, reflecting $0.08 of one-time productivity charges in Q2 of last fiscal year. 
Turning to the P&L scorecard, foreign exchange reduced the top and bottom line by about 2.5%. Excluding this FX impact on a constant currency x items basis, sales grew 2.9%, driven by organic sales growth of 3.3%. Importantly, all of our segments posted positive organic sales growth in the quarter.
Gross margin was up 40 basis points and constant currency gross profit grew 4.1%. We continue to increase our investment in marketing and in additional capabilities. Operating income is up slightly despite the increased P&L investments. And finally, as mentioned, EPS was up nearly 14%.
As projected during last quarter's call, Q2 EPS benefited from a favorable tax rate at about 10%. This largely reflects foreign tax planning initiatives. In short, we delivered solid top and bottom line growth while with favorable tax rate enabled us to make significant investments in the business.
Looking at the key components around revenue growth. Organic sales growth of 3.3% was driven by both volume and price. Volume growth of 1.4% was led by U.S. consumer products, the U.K., Brazil, Russia and China sauces, partially offset by the declines in The Netherlands and Italy. Price improvements of 1.9% were led by Brazil, Venezuela, Indonesia, U.S. Foodservice and Continental Europe. And excluding the impact of the prior year decisions to exit T.G.I. frozen meals, and downsize our Long Fong frozen business in China, organic sales growth was 4.1% for the quarter. And finally, our top line was unfavorably impacted by 2 prior period divestitures and by foreign exchange.
Our 40 basis point improvement in gross margin was led by the U.S. businesses, along with Russia, Australia and Brazil. Market inflation of commodities was about 4% in the quarter, tomatoes, potatoes and sweeteners. And looking forward, we expect around 4% market inflation on the balance of the year, largely in line with our original projections.
Let's take a quick look at top and bottom line performance in each one of our key segments. In North American consumer products, we're encouraged that the progress the team is making to drive profitable growth. Organic sales were up slightly as volume increased 1.2% and net price decreased 0.8% as we optimize price points on the Ore-Ida and Classico brands. Excluding the impact of selling off of Boston Market license and exit of T.G.I. frozen meals, U.S. retail sales grew by nearly 4% and our strongest performance in 9 quarters. Importantly, gross margin was up 70 basis points driven by strong productivity, while operating income reflected a significant increase in marketing spend.
Our U.S. Foodservice business posted excellent results for the quarter. Sales up more than 4% and profit up almost 27%. Net price increased about 4% driven by pricing actions taken in the second half last year to offset inflation. And volume was roughly flat overall reflecting current restaurant industry traffic trends.
The business posted strong gross margin and operating income growth as a result of higher sales, effective cost management and the benefit from prior year productivity initiatives. Across the platform, constant currency results in Europe were about flat for the quarter. Organic sales were slightly positive as double-digit growth in Russia was enough to offset the impact of a weak economy in soft category sales in Italy. U.K. volume was up despite cool weather during barbecue season, but net price was down. Importantly, market share gains were saved in our large soup, beans and ketchup businesses.
Higher gross margins, driven by productivity improvements, which outpaced that commodity inflation. And constant currency operating income was flat to prior year, driven by higher market investments, partially offset by lower SG&A spending.
Asia/Pacific posted very strong results with constant currency sales up 4% and profit up almost 27%. Organic sales growth was 4.1%. Emerging Markets continue to post strong growth while our developed markets also delivered organic sales growth in the quarter.
Volume was up nearly 2% led primarily by very strong growth in sauces in China and Indonesia, partially offset by Long Fong and the timing of Ramadan. Price was up more than 2%, driven by a double-digit increase in Indonesia to cover commodity inflation. The region achieved strong gross margin growth up 30 basis points driven by Australia, New Zealand and China. Both emerging and developed markets posted strong double-digit operating income growth.
And as Bill noted, we're very pleased with the turnaround in Australia. Operating income grew significantly this quarter, a result of a targeted actions we took to improve commercial capabilities, simplify the business, reduce costs and focus on better day to day execution.
Now turning to our Rest of World segment. We posted organic and constant currency sales growth of nearly 20% with all regions delivered double-digit organic sales growth. Volume increased by 6.5% led by Brazil where we achieved strong market share growth in vegetables, ketchup and pasta sauces. Notably, Quero recently began the #1 brand of vegetables in Brazil.
Mexico also achieved strong volume growth in the quarter as our Ketchup in baby food businesses attained record market shares and October. The net price increased by 13%, led by strong pricing in South America. Gross profit dollars increased with the gross margin decreased as a result of high inflation cost in Venezuela and operating income reflects lower profitability in Venezuela and increased investments in marketing capabilities in Brazil.
And moving to cash. Operating free cash flow was $155 million for the quarter, up $24 million driven by higher net income and slightly lower capital spending. During the quarter, we repurchased 1.1 million shares at a total cost of $62 million,, partially offset by cash from options. This is in line with our stated goal of keeping diluted shares flat for the year.
Let's take a very brief look at the results for the first half. On a constant currency basis, year-to-date sales are up 3.5%, operating income up almost 3% and EPS up more than 14%. For the first half, organic sales are up 4%, gross margin has increased and we've continued to invest in both marketing and capabilities.
The year-to-date tax rate is about 14% and drive EPS would fund our investments in the business. And looking at the balance sheet scorecard. Capital spending is flat to prior year as a percentage of revenue. Cash conversion cycle improved significantly, down 6 days to 38 days largely, driven by better inventory management. Year-to-date cash flow of $131 million is below prior year, due to the timing of receivable securitization and cash taxes. We expect is in the rate cash flow in the back of the fiscal year consistent with our typical annual phasing.
Net debt-to-EBITDA is flat to prior year and remains low at 2.1x. And ROIC has increased nearly 200 basis points, reflecting higher net income and the benefits from last year's productivity initiatives.
Now, let's switch gears, and I'd like to make a comments in the second half of the fiscal year. As Bill said, we are reaffirming our reason out top and bottom line outlook. The second half, we expect increased innovation and 4%-plus organic sales growth. Accelerating gross margin improvements, incremental investment of global marketing, Emerging Markets sales capabilities and the SAP program and higher effective tax rate, which is anticipated to be in the low- to mid-20s during the third quarter and a bit higher in the fourth quarter. For the full year, we expect the rate of around 20%. EPS should be at about the same level in Q3 and Q4 this year, which is in line with our full year constant currency outlook.
So in summary, we're posting solid sales and EPS results in a challenging environment, driving strong top line growth in Emerging Markets, Global Ketchup and our Top 15 Brands, delivering higher gross margin despite the difficult market environment and making significant investments in the business enabled by a favorable tax rate.
With that, we'll turn it back to Meg to take your questions. Meg?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, Ken, as we continue to expand even more outside the United States, and particularly in some of these Emerging Markets have low flat taxes and very low parties for tax planning and our guys do a very good job of exercising those opportunities and leveraging them. So our view is going forward us Art said, for certainly for next fiscal year, I think we feel pretty good about being fairly consistent with this year I'm going to say anything be a next fiscal year because they have no idea what's going to happen to tax regimes around the world, but certainly, for the next 6 quarters, the 2 this year and next year, before next year, we should be in pretty good shape.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well let me step back and category a minute and lets talk about spectacle about our business. The category over the last 5 years has lost 20 million cases, about 1/3 of the total category volume. It's lost $500 million in sales. Within that period, our ov
componenttext: Well let me step back and category a minute and lets talk about spectacle about our business. The category over the last 5 years has lost 20 million cases, about 1/3 of the total category volume. It's lost $500 million in sales. Within that period, our overall business as we define it, is up 2.5 to 3 share points. Currently, what we're seeing is very strong performance on our breakfast business, good performance in some of our sides and in terms of the snacks, and our based entree business while we are not promoting as aggressively as maybe we could and that's a decision we have made and so the focus is really been in frozen on getting Ore-Ida and our snack business growing, which we did successfully in the second quarter. So generally Smart Ones was not as strong in the second quarter as I think we would have liked. We'll see how the season plays out. But my bigger issue, continues to be the nutritional category were industry is lost about 1/3 of it sales over the last 5 years. And so rather than chasing volume in, in the category but still not sure where it's going, we're planning on innovation we're doing a lot of good things, particularly on breakfast, which is the fastest-growing daypart in the freezer case and really focusing our other efforts on Ore-Ida and frozen snacks businesses, which are performing quite well.

componenttextpreview: It's doing very well in the Hispanic markets, where we've supported between multilingual advertising, Spanish-language advertising, particularly on the West Coast parts of the Southwest and on the Northeast. And so I would say it's been a key component of
componenttext: It's doing very well in the Hispanic markets, where we've supported between multilingual advertising, Spanish-language advertising, particularly on the West Coast parts of the Southwest and on the Northeast. And so I would say it's been a key component of our success in this market since it's moved in to the top 10 SKUs that we sell in those areas and other markets I think we need to do a better job of getting more prominent distribution but generally, it's playing in line in most markets, with where we thought it would be and the Hispanic markets doing much better. And they think outside the U.S., doy pack continues to be an incredible will to the business and Indonesia, it's majority of our growth is coming in condiments and sauces, which is being led by doy packs, same thing in Russia. The launch in Mexico has been nothing more than heroic success in fact we can supply baby food in Mexico, we just started up another landing in Guadeljara but we are literally out-of-stock we launched 3 SKUs in baby food last year. We're now up to 5 soon to be 7 or 8. Our shares now in double digits and the same thing on Ketchup where we're now at close to 20 shares in Mexico from 0 3 or 4 years ago again most of that is being, driven by doy pack. We've launched in the U.K. so if doy pack is going to be a clear component of the company's success going forward, particularly given the price point, and in the U.S., I'm pleased with where we are in Hispanic markets and I think will see more upside going forward from doy pack. And I think the other things you can count on is a lot more doy pack initiatives around the company, both in developed and Emerging Markets going beyond just Ketchup.

But no, I don't think right now I'm concerned about that time concern about getting on the shelf dollar stores.

componenttext: Just my one question that would be in relation to the North American business, and you certainly have made some pretty heavy marketing investments and we're starting to see some social sales recoveries and momentum in the business and I think you've outlined, Bill, higher gross margin for the quarter. I just wanted to understand if the division I guess to get your assessment of the progression at the top line commented if you think that business can grow its profits this year given the investments you're making?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of responses there. First, if you back out T.G.I.F. in the quarter, we U.S. business was up over 4 points in volume growth. So the U.S. business is responded the marketing, which is frankly balance of promotion and media and traditional mark
componenttext: Yes, a couple of responses there. First, if you back out T.G.I.F. in the quarter, we U.S. business was up over 4 points in volume growth. So the U.S. business is responded the marketing, which is frankly balance of promotion and media and traditional marketing support. And I think we feel pretty good about where we're headed from a volume standpoint once we get the noise of T.G.I.F. behind us and we do have touch rest the Smart Ones question that was raised earlier. I think from a profit standpoint, I would be very pleased to see with the U.S. company coming in plus or minus a few points versus last year. Will just depend on how much investment we make in the second half. We had a significant increase in I want to underline the word significant in the second quarter. We don't breakout marketing standing by business unit for a lot of obvious reasons. But it is not unreasonable to say marketing spending in the U.S. was up well into the double digits in the second quarter, the bulk of that behind Ketchup and the Hispanic advertising and some advertising in Southeast on Ore-Ida in addition to some stuff we have done on Classico and frankly on steps. So I think that I feel better about the prospects that the U.S. going forward from a top line standpoint and share standpoint most recent shares 65% volume growth in my comments, but in the last 4 weeks, volume share growth was almost 78% of the total business so we are seeing a response but there's no doubt that we are intentionally pressuring profits in the U.S. this year as we work to restore the top line growth. Fortunately, we're able to do that, that only because of the tax rate but because of the strength to food service business and the strength of our Emerging Markets businesses in terms of growing the bottom line. So I think one of the benefits of front of followed a company like we do use it gives us enormous amount of flexibility in terms of where we reprioritize investment. So it gives a significant investment increases in the U.S. as we continue to drive the topline.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: What I've been pretty consistent, Chris, for almost 4 years I'm not going to chase a declining market and I continue to believe that so we're monitoring the market and try to be as balanced as we can in terms of how we predators are investment dollars in
componenttext: What I've been pretty consistent, Chris, for almost 4 years I'm not going to chase a declining market and I continue to believe that so we're monitoring the market and try to be as balanced as we can in terms of how we predators are investment dollars in right now I'm getting a significant positive return on Ore-Ida I'm seeing a good response in frozen snacks and I'm seeing a terrific growth upside in Ketchup. And so as a consequence of that, we'll put investments behind where we're seen the growth. If I could a lot of investment behind Smart Ones and I'm chasing a declining market, there's just not going to be the return I want. So as I said, breakfast is doing well, we do activity during the coming during the season in terms of innovation and some new products that we've got some interesting things over the longer term the deals over the next 6 to 12 months in Smart Ones. I certainly don't want to imply that we're working with the business because were in a district important to was but I think you can read into that, that the dollars we're allocating for investment in the freezer case were going to put first where we're getting our best return, which in this case right now is Ore-Ida and snacks and we'll manage the Smart Ones business the best way we can. And right now I would tell you that by still think innovation and marketing behind Smart Ones is the way to go rather than get into a football promotion initiative that ultimately nobody wins. But until the category start stabilizing again, I just hate to chase volume.

componenttext: I was going to ask a question that's us a little bit in line with what Bill was just addressing, which was you mentioned 2/3 of the business is having volume growth and are you going to focus on bending the trend on the remaining 1/3, like on Smart Ones? headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. And again, David, as I said it in the last 4 weeks with 78% of our business in volume growth in the U.S. So what we're trying to understand is that where we're getting the best leverage both from a top line standpoint and a bottom line st
componenttext: Yes, I think so. And again, David, as I said it in the last 4 weeks with 78% of our business in volume growth in the U.S. So what we're trying to understand is that where we're getting the best leverage both from a top line standpoint and a bottom line standpoint if you saw the margin improvement in the quarter, because our investments behind our leading American margin brands, which would be Ketchup and Ore-Ida gives us good response in the quarter I think so we're going to be at the balance it. And I've been very pleased with the turnaround in Ore-Ida. I continue to believe Ketchup is still an opportunity in the U.S. I think the new package launch in the U.S. behind something we have internally name for that basically leads to transforming the Ketchup category is something that's we're very excited about we've launched 38 and 34-ounce sizes. And in specialty items in 14 ounce sizes the consumer response in has been extraordinary. The Hispanic response in terms of where we are with our marketing efforts is the right so we what we're doing is we're choosing and prioritizing in just where we had the greatest leverage east to the P&L and to the top line. And so yes, I mean, it's not necessarily an issue of triage, but it's going to be an issue who's going to give you the best return for incremental dollars.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a story of 2 tales really, 2 cities. Virtually, every other business in the Rest of the World segment grew margin, including Brazil, which grew their margin significantly. To was a nation of Venezuela. And part of the Venezuela relates to the ti
componenttext: Yes, it's a story of 2 tales really, 2 cities. Virtually, every other business in the Rest of the World segment grew margin, including Brazil, which grew their margin significantly. To was a nation of Venezuela. And part of the Venezuela relates to the timing of the elections and the trade backing off in terms of buying product in the inflation rate, which we have not been able to price out to in the Venezuelan market. So I think if you back Venezuela out of the Rest of the World, you'll see a dramatically different margin growth story, particularly in Brazil or I was very pleased we grew margin 200 to 300 basis points of the quarter in Brazil. I think the second thing that you need to keep in mind is we are coming off in the Rest of the World an incredible quarter last year. We are up 150 basis points, 150% last in operating profit. And so we knew Rest of World from a bottom line standpoint was not going to have the kind of quarter we had last year. But I have to tell you that Brazilian business has been nothing more than a continued surprise to me in terms of how well it is doing. We're seeing continued growth in Mexico, great performance and the rest of Latin America Latin America ex-Venezuela really strong results coming out of the Middle East. And so I feel pretty good about where we are but that, as well as the story of the Rest of World and the second quarter in terms of the dilution on margin. And that to address itself over time as the they finished elections in December on the state basis and then we get some clarity on what's going to happen going forward.

So we actually are doing well relative to the category.

componenttext: Can you guys update us on the incremental investment plan for the year? When you laid out the year back in the fourth quarter Analyst Day, the plan for the year was to incrementally put $120 million into the business, $70 million in the marketing and I think about $50 million into a number of areas to increase your capabilities. So I'd like to hear about both areas. And then one thing I would say I think my numbers right now, I've got marketing for the first 6 months of the year come up about $10 million or about 4%. So if everything is in-line and that would suggest a fairly massive marketing reinvestment in the final 2 quarters, and I'm curious if that plan has changed at all?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: The plan has not changed, but you're looking at actual currency as opposed to constant currency and we were up 13% in the second quarter and we are up year-to-date between 8% and 10%.So I think we're tracking right where we thought whether we would be and
componenttext: The plan has not changed, but you're looking at actual currency as opposed to constant currency and we were up 13% in the second quarter and we are up year-to-date between 8% and 10%.So I think we're tracking right where we thought whether we would be and I will tell you some of that marketing may be deployed a little differently in the second half of the year we make with some promotion depending on the market and depending on where we are. But we are still on track for the investments significant investments in boots on the ground in the Emerging Markets editor of interest if you look at the 3 markets that benefited the most, China condiments and sauces, Russia and Brazil, those are were 3 best-performing emerging market businesses along with Indonesia during the second quarter into the first half of the year, I mean Russia sales are organically up around 14% obviously condiments and sauces you saw in China up around 20% and Brazil up around 33%. So we're seeing good response from that. We've made significant investments in SAP, particularly in Canada and now in Europe we've just turned Spain on following the success of Germany so we continue to roll out those investments. Marketing spend is as I said on a constant currency basis is up 8% to 10% so for this year, very strong the second quarter. So we're about where we thought we would be, David. I think the qualification I'll give you the second half we see better leverage on the promotions side, that's where we'll go and having said that, I want to but clear that promotion spending is defined by deal spending for the company is not up year-on-year for the first half of the year. I would be anymore specific than that for a lot of reasons, but we are not up. So the opportunity to deploy differently will be predicated on the category, the country, the business and word the opportunities are. But we're still tracking for double-digit increase in marketing spend it on a constant currency basis, which is how we defined in May and for substantial improvement in capabilities around the company and we're seeing really good returns on that even SAP in Europe we're starting to see a very positive response from the investments in the Benelux a couple of years ago, Spain is gone extremely well, Germany has gone in well was alluded the German business in the rest of the Continental Europe when we sold the whatever business earlier this year. So our plans have not changed. The prioritization of how those dollars are allocated may be modified a bit in the second half.

componenttextpreview: Well right now we're going to stick with the guidance we have because we have and will then of the numbers relative to the guidance and so I think in that context, Rob, I don't want to be anymore enlightened or enlightening in terms of how we're going to
componenttext: Well right now we're going to stick with the guidance we have because we have and will then of the numbers relative to the guidance and so I think in that context, Rob, I don't want to be anymore enlightened or enlightening in terms of how we're going to do that. The other thinning you got to remember, we're doing with the roads are right now that we can figure out. I mean, and the turmoil in the road, we generally fiscal cliff is going to be resolved you tell me how wrist Europe is going to persecute him he was going to happen to currency in the second half of the year you felt he was going to happen to consumer confidence at the right now we're seating undiluted a better sense early as we approach the end of this calendar year and into the beginning of the next calendar year how the stuff unfolds. Right now, Europe, you're dealing with various austerity and tax regimes that aren't working very well in the efficacy of those is being challenged. We've got consumer unhappiness throughout the European continent but, particularly in Southern Europe and the Iberian Peninsula. we're seeing similar things happening in the U.S. as Foodservice traffic now sort of reflects the anticipation of what's going to happen with the cliff. I don't share the confidence and our political process and others seem to be believing in. And so I think from our standpoint, we're just seating until we know where we are. The other thing I will tell you, tax is never a certainty but, while we followed pretty good about where we are, things happen. And so I think we just want to keep where we're going and work from that. I'm pleased with the execution of the company, I'm pleased with where we're headed. I think Emerging Markets continue to look very promising and if anything, it would continue to invest in more boots on the ground in Emerging Markets before I'd probably put more into specific marketing. I mean, the boots on the ground is giving us a very solid tangible return in all of these markets. I'd like to see us do a little bit more in Indonesia and maybe a little bit more in India. And then we have a lot of other initiatives in place.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can I ask a question on cash flow to Art it's down $98 million year-to-date for operating cash flow, but net income is up and the tax rate is down your CapEx is pretty stable. What was the driver again for the cash flow? And should we see a big improvemen
componenttext: Can I ask a question on cash flow to Art it's down $98 million year-to-date for operating cash flow, but net income is up and the tax rate is down your CapEx is pretty stable. What was the driver again for the cash flow? And should we see a big improvement? I think you're guiding to $1.1 billion in cash flow for the year, has that changed?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Rob, not of it is primarily the associated we cash tax payments as you know book tax versus cash taxes it's often very differently time. So that's certainly part of it also the timing of some of our securitization activities is different this year than in
componenttext: Rob, not of it is primarily the associated we cash tax payments as you know book tax versus cash taxes it's often very differently time. So that's certainly part of it also the timing of some of our securitization activities is different this year than in prior years. So net-net, we expect strong back half. We're projecting through $1 billion plus in terms of operating free cash flow. And I think we want to maintain some flexibility there in terms of the level of capital spending, particularly as it relates to Emerging Markets. So I think $1 billion plus we feel good about at this point.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Bill, you wanted to get back to the volume a little bit and particularly your strategy surrounding that. When and a look over the past 4 years, it's been did you see some significant volume declines across base of Europe, certainly Foodservice and North A
componenttext: Bill, you wanted to get back to the volume a little bit and particularly your strategy surrounding that. When and a look over the past 4 years, it's been did you see some significant volume declines across base of Europe, certainly Foodservice and North America? And here, it's notable that the first quarter I believe in a while where you had a negative divided price mix. So you were moderating for pricing commutes in sequential improvement in volumes. So I wondered if it seems like broadly in the food industry now, consumers have reacted to brand lowering prices by improving volume that's what the data is telling us. And is there do you expect a period where you're going to invest in price a little bit more to drive more volume? I know you've called out some categories that you that think are not worth it, but do you intend to keep that going and accelerate volume through it just these price investments are working in that direction?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a mix of categories in the mix of countries in a mix of businesses. I think generally, historical truths are true, which is few lower price, consumers will respond. But I think a lot of what we are doing is being, driven by makes and the way that siz
componenttext: It's a mix of categories in the mix of countries in a mix of businesses. I think generally, historical truths are true, which is few lower price, consumers will respond. But I think a lot of what we are doing is being, driven by makes and the way that sizing, the price points in terms of smaller sizes and in terms of different kinds of recipes and so forth, Jonathan. But I think as I said a few minutes ago, and in response to David's question about marketing spend in the second half, if we believe we can generate a better return by leveraging more promotion as opposed to just generalized traditional marketing, that's the way we will go. But it will depend on the business. In ketchup right now in the U.S., we're getting a great response in very traditional advertising. As we are Ore-Ida after balancing what we needed to be on price in the Emerging Markets, we're getting very good price and that you could remember in those markets you have general inflation, which is also be reflected in wages and so forth, so the consumer is not us put off by price and private label is not a big issue. But I think generally, even in the developed world, private label's no longer showing the kind of growth they did it it's really going to be a function of creating value in the mind of the consumer, whether that value manifests itself in terms of better innovation, premium product, superior performance or a combination of promoted volume and/or better price points, it's just going to depend on the category and on where we think we'll getting the best return. And clearly, some of these businesses, price is going to be a better leverage than other businesses. Clearly, in other cases, market is going to be a better lever and what we're trying to do is to evaluate on the elasticity basis exactly where we get the greatest leverage.

componenttext: I actually don't have that number. Again, Top 15 Brands come if you exclude and I think in this case you'd have to T.G.I.F. out, we're well up over 5% organically. And since much of that was driven by ABC, Brazil and the Heinz brand, I would guess off the top of my mind that 1/3 of that's volume related than 2/3 of it is price related but it could be more like 40-60. There is volume growth in their and there is some price growth in there because of the mix of the emerging market businesses in there.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I want to circle back to the cash flow statement and build on some of Rob's questions. CapEx is running a little bit lighter than I think your initial 3.8 -- sorry, 3.8% to 4% guidance for the year. Is what we've seen in the first half more reflective of
componenttext: I want to circle back to the cash flow statement and build on some of Rob's questions. CapEx is running a little bit lighter than I think your initial 3.8 -- sorry, 3.8% to 4% guidance for the year. Is what we've seen in the first half more reflective of what the full year is going to come in or should we stick with that 3.8% to 4%?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we'll right around 3.8% to 4% we could be 3.7%, we could be 3.9% because we have a lot of investments in the second half of the year in the Emerging Markets. It's finishing the Shanghai factory, which I'm hoping will be open early in the new calen
componenttext: I think we'll right around 3.8% to 4% we could be 3.7%, we could be 3.9% because we have a lot of investments in the second half of the year in the Emerging Markets. It's finishing the Shanghai factory, which I'm hoping will be open early in the new calendar year. We have started the China baby food factory, which we all going to open in 2015. We've got a lot of investment going into India. We also have SAP investment community second half of the year. And obviously, the finalization of the Innovation Center in Europe. There's a fair amount of capital investment established in the second half the year. Frankly, my perspective is the lower I can keep that number, the happier I am. As everybody works for me knows. The realities, given the pressure we have on volume in the Emerging Markets, we have to provide capacity. Says it, we put a new punchline into Mexico, we have a second one coming very shortly. We have a new punch line going to Brazil we have second one of those come in very shortly. We've got are starting to produce Ketchup in Brazil in the next 30 or 40 days. I think we've also got a fair amount of activity in the Asian markets, China in particular. It's an area we're going to have to put it to invest in. So I think will be right around that number. To be honest with you, if I'd have my numbers I don't bring it down but right now given the SAP implementation and the capacity needs a have in that business, I can't. The final things we're pretty much out of capacity and we're going to look at different squeeze were the plan goes is yet to be determined. It'll be interesting to see where that line goes I think you should not assume that line is automatically going into the U.S. if that is the line we will have to start talking about in the second half of the year because we're out of capacity in the Emerging Markets are all yelling and screaming at me afford the increased capabilities. So it's mainly about SAP implementation and about adding capacity in the Emerging Markets where we're getting significant growth.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012

componenttext: One more question and I'll pass it on. You're your sales growth guidance of 4%. Your prior comparisons become a more onerous as we get to the back half. Bill, can you detail some of the initiatives that you have in place that are going to help you try of that growth?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2013 Earnings Call, Nov 20, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there was a couple of things to keep in mind. One, we're spending lot of marketing we better see that kind of volume growth in the second half the year. Secondly, innovation in the U.K. is up 50% year-on-year in the second half. We have a sig
componenttext: Yes, I think there was a couple of things to keep in mind. One, we're spending lot of marketing we better see that kind of volume growth in the second half the year. Secondly, innovation in the U.K. is up 50% year-on-year in the second half. We have a significant amount of innovation in the Emerging Markets, particularly behind couch initiatives. We've got significant amount of innovation coming in the U.S. more, which I'll detail at CAGNY. We have a lot of activity in other parts of Europe as well, particularly in Eastern Europe and Russia. So there's a significant amount of new product activity in the second half of the year and a significant response to the marketing spending that we have initiated in the first half the year from a much of this really didn't begin until the second quarter and you will see follow-through in the third quarter. So I think in that context, I feel reasonably sanguine. Let me underline those 2 words, reasonably sanguine, about strong volume growth or strong organic sales growth in the second half of the year. The Emerging Markets as I said last year at this time, relative to the second half should be much stronger in the second half for this year than they were in the first half of this year. We're seeing huge pickup in Brazil, hopefully the new Ketchup line will be ready. We've launched Heinz tomatoes paste it's doing very well. The enabling lines we've now put in Mexico allows to start shipping baby food more aggressively. What we're doing in Indonesia with the launch in the second half, which are all predominantly condiments and sauces launches. A lot of activity in terms of our expansion of our food condiments and sauces business in China, as well as some food service initiative and the focus on Ketchup to continue to the strength of Ketchup in the European condiment. And then just the general success of Russia should help us drive volume in the second half of the year. I feel pretty good about the third quarter. The fourth quarter is really where we're going to have the measurement year-on-year. But the forecast coming in from our operating teams are all pretty optimistic about volume growth there is organic sales growth in the second half the year so right now, we see no reason to backlog that than a reminder, we have generated about 4% in the first off this year and that's what we have the benefit of some of the marketing that you'll see in the second half.

componenttextpreview: Anne, if we don't need hit it before fiscal '16, I would be incredibly disappointed and highly annoyed with a lot of the people who have worked for me. We have this first quarter I can say it's not what we have so many active M&A initiatives in the Emergi
componenttext: Anne, if we don't need hit it before fiscal '16, I would be incredibly disappointed and highly annoyed with a lot of the people who have worked for me. We have this first quarter I can say it's not what we have so many active M&A initiatives in the Emerging Markets we literally had a meeting last week to decide how we're going to put them in priority. We have a number of very close in initiatives underway in the 3 markets I've mentioned in my initial comments. As well as other markets where I think we need to improve our footprint. For perspective, I just came up from 15-day around the world trip where I was in various parts of Asia and various parts of Europe and we are aggressively looking out and aggressively in the process of M&A activity. And yes, I will be very, very disappointed if we're not 30% before fiscal '16. I really will. And there's no guarantee obviously, people really don't care my level of disappointment but I will tell you, that I would be surprised and unhappy if we're not there first, given what we have both organically in terms of the opportunities for the new capacity we're adding and the M&A initiatives we have underway.

componenttext: Okay, I don't know how much contribute the quarter. And in terms of volume going forward I mean, clearly, and they are should you're talking to U.S. but if you're not, please let me know. I think the management team in the U.S. is done an excellent job of refocusing on integration I was at the Innovation Center in North America weeks ago Friday and spend the whole afternoon with reviewing new product initiatives underway and some of the activities that'll start keeping the market late in this fiscal year, which will have some benefit in Q4 but really should have the bulk of their benefit next year beyond the pipeline fill. So again, lot of excuse me, a lot of activity in potatoes, a lot of activity and sauces and a lot of activity other areas that I think will be interesting. If you look at our business, the strongest category growth in any of our businesses in developed markets is vinegar, and barbecue sauces the U.S. Vinegar is growing as category a at double-digit rates as ROE and so we're going to leverage that and look for opportunities there as well. So again,, there's some opportunities in the second half the year drive better volume than we did in the first half in the U.S. company.

componenttextpreview: Same way. I mean, I think right now, if you go back to the Senate Bill, the Senate built-up dividend tax of 20%-plus a 3.8% Medicare tax. The President wants to take ordinary income tax the Republicans want to keep it at 15 points plus a 3.8%. So I think
componenttext: Same way. I mean, I think right now, if you go back to the Senate Bill, the Senate built-up dividend tax of 20%-plus a 3.8% Medicare tax. The President wants to take ordinary income tax the Republicans want to keep it at 15 points plus a 3.8%. So I think there's likelihood be some kind of compromise on dividend tax. So Lemos of our investors, Eric am are still telling us to prefer to seat in the form of dividends and share buybacks and so our strategy continues to be in terms of the deployment of cash M&A and as I said, we have an aggressive pipeline M&A. A lot of initiatives underway several, of which I'd hope would get done sooner rather than later but we'll see as you know that's a tricky game. And the second use of cash and obviously we're content to buy back stock in order to prevent dilution from outstanding shares. But right now, we don't see a change. I don't how the fiscal cliff is going to manifest itself how's it going to manage out obviously if we start hearing from our investors and we start seeing a dramatic shift then we'll be flexible in terms of what's going to rate the most value. It's just right now our belief is based on what we're hearing, that dividends are still the best way for us to deploy cash back to our investors. That may change and if it does, that obviously we'll modify our approach but right now that's where we are.
